summary: In May 1940, Germany advanced into France, trapping Allied troops on the beaches of Dunkirk. Under air and ground cover from British and French forces, troops were slowly and methodically evacuated from the beach using every serviceable naval and civilian vessel that could be found. At the end of this heroic mission, 330,000 French, British, Belgian and Dutch soldiers were safely evacuated.

reviews.content: Incredible scenes. Sensitively handled. The story of Dunkirk as well told as anyone might possibly hope for.
The soundtracks and the different angles at the scenes that were taken are amazing, the movie really made me focused and interested in what was going on throughout the movie. The acting was amazing.

"Dunkirk," directed by Christopher Nolan, is a World War II film that tells the story of the evacuation of British and Allied forces from the beaches of Dunkirk, France, in 1940. The film is a masterful example of visual storytelling, with a stunning visual and auditory experience that immerses the viewer in the intensity and chaos of the evacuation.

One of the most striking aspects of "Dunkirk" is its non-linear narrative structure. The story is told through three interwoven timelines, each representing a different perspective of the evacuation: soldiers on the beach, pilots in the air, and civilians on boats crossing the English Channel. This approach creates a sense of tension and urgency, as the viewer is left to piece together the events and understand the wider context of the evacuation.

The film's cinematography, courtesy of Hoyte van Hoytema, is breathtaking. The use of large format cameras and practical effects creates a visceral and realistic experience that captures the enormity of the evacuation. The wide shots of the beach, the close-ups of the soldiers' faces, and the breathtaking aerial dogfights are all visually stunning and add to the film's overall impact.

The film's score, composed by Hans Zimmer, is also a standout feature. The score features a haunting and relentless ticking sound, which adds to the film's tension and urgency. Zimmer's music is a critical element of the film's emotional impact, providing a powerful and effective backdrop for the action on the screen.

The cast, which includes Tom Hardy, Kenneth Branagh, Mark Rylance, and Fionn Whitehead, all deliver strong performances. Despite the minimal dialogue and character development, the actors convey the desperation, fear, and hopelessness that define the evacuation of Dunkirk.

In summary, "Dunkirk" is a remarkable achievement in visual storytelling. The film's non-linear narrative structure, stunning cinematography, haunting score, and powerful performances combine to create an immersive and emotional experience that transports the viewer to the heart of one of the most significant events in modern history. Christopher Nolan's masterful direction and attention to detail make "Dunkirk" a must-see movie for anyone interested in cinema or history.

"Dunkirk" is a 2017 war/action movie directed by Christopher Nolan. The film tells the story of the Dunkirk evacuation, a pivotal event in World War II, from the perspectives of soldiers, pilots, and civilians who were caught up in the conflict.

One of the strengths of this film is its impressive use of non-linear storytelling. The movie jumps back and forth between different timelines and perspectives, creating a sense of tension and urgency that is both engaging and thought-provoking. The cinematography is also top-notch, with stunning aerial shots and impressive use of practical effects to create a sense of authenticity and realism.

The acting in the film is solid, with notable performances from Mark Rylance, Tom Hardy, and Kenneth Branagh. The actors do an excellent job of conveying the emotions and experiences of their characters, without resorting to overly dramatic or contrived performances.

The music by Hans Zimmer is also a standout feature of the film, adding a sense of urgency and tension that complements the action and visuals perfectly.

One potential weakness of the film is its lack of character development. While the movie does an excellent job of conveying the physical and emotional toll of war, it doesn't give much insight into the individual motivations or personalities of the characters. However, this is a deliberate choice by the director, who wanted to emphasize the broader themes of survival and sacrifice.

Overall, "Dunkirk" is a masterful and intense war/action movie that manages to be both gripping and thought-provoking. Its impressive use of non-linear storytelling, stunning cinematography, and excellent musical score make it a must-see for fans of the genre.

Dunkirk ist ein historischer Kriegsfilm von Christopher Nolan. Die Geschichte wurde bildgewaltig, gefühlsbetont und doch faktenbasiert inszeniert. Weil der Film arm an Dialogen und dagegen voll von dichter Handlung ist, kommt der Musik und den Sound eine wichtige Rolle zu, und die wurde von Hans Zimmer hervorragend erfüllt. Dunkirk ist ein sehenswerter Film.

This movie has outstanding visuals and sounds, the close up shots is immaculate. They used quite a few different camera techniques that changed the ratio from full screen to wide view for different scenes. Alot of the scenes rely on its visuals and sounds to create an emotional impact. Sometimes there is scenes that has no dialogues between the characters. It isn't a movie with back stories about characters but starts in the middle of their survival, which many people didn't like about this because they expected something different, rather than just to follow characters on their survival. Personally I think Christopher Nolan did absolutely superbly, maybe not for Tom Hardy, like what was he saying? I'm sure Tommy was taking a major dump after all this. The actors really acted their characters well I didn't see them as actors at all what so ever only the characters, and I didn't know it was Harry Styles, like what? For it's cinematography and it's surrealism sound, how can I not give this a high score. This is based on soldiers at war evacuating at Dunkirk, I wasn't there, I don't know what it's like being a Soldier but it's not a blockbuster that has to have one character with dramatic lines, no one is going to be quoting Shakespeare during battle. This movie is definitely one of my favorites.

I love this movie. Its masterful portrayal of the horrors of WWII made me admittedly more emotional than I usually am while watching movies. Its characters are great, and it looks amazing. The only thing keeping it from being 5 stars for me is the sometimes hard to follow timing of the movie. It frequently jumps around time, which can be quite confusing. For some people this use of time jumps could enhance the viewing experience, but it could certainly be seen as needlessly confusing. Nonetheless, the movie is one of Nolan's finest. Definitely recommend!
Amazing film , this is a must watch.

Dunkirk is a solid war film and a must-watch for any Nolan enthusiasts or war film purest, but for a Director who I had always said, "Christopher Nolan should make a World War 2 movie" and who had the perfect style of dark, gritty, and envelope-pushing material...I sure was let down by this movie. Upon first viewing, this movie can be needlessly confusing, which is nothing new for a Nolan film but where movies like Interstellar, Inception, or Memento can benefit from being a little confusing forcing the audience to figure it out themselves. But a war film like Dunkirk doesn't really benefit from this style of storytelling, it's a very suspenseful movie at times but loses all of that by not delivering on any consequences for the characters.
Nolan's most intimate movie. Masterpiece of its genre.
You can really see what is going through the mind of soldiers who are just trying to survive.

"Dunkirk", at least for me, is the perfect example that cinema is not only made with technical aspects. The film is undeniably well acted and photographed, and the sound work is excellent, but it's so, so, SO BORING! Hans Zimmer tries to accentuate the drama and the tension with the soundtrack, but it didn't work for me, I'm sorry. It's also hard to talk about the performances, as nobody here is memorable or highlighted. Harry Styles (whose presence annoyed me a lot) is just a soldier, like Fionn Whitehead and Aneurin Barnard. Cillian Murphy is just a man in a panic, Tom Hardy exists as a pilot, and so does Jack Lowden. Incredible as it may seem, I think the most memorable character is the Commander, made by Kenneth Branagh. KENNETH. BRANAGH. The film has three parallel narratives, each one with different duration: the mole, one week; the sea, one day; the air, one hour. The transitions between them are a bit problematic, I found myself lost in time several times, not only in time but also during an aerial fight; fortunately, the air battle problem is solved from the second onwards. If I was involved with the story (the "story" is actually "watch this war from different points of view for 1h46min), "Dunkirk" could be an amazing sensorial experience, like both "Blade Runner" movies were, or an even better comparison (with another war film), like "1917" was, but, unfortunately, this is not what happened. I recognize the extraordinary technical job, but it's not enough. It's almost unbelievable that after doing a potentially emotionally powerful movie ("Interstellar"), Christopher Nolan did an almost empty one.
Incredible movie. I don't rewatch movies often, but this one I do. Also the soundtrack is amazing.
i didnt expect to like this movie so much to be completely honest, but its so worth it, it is amazing

I didn't enjoy this film at all. I found the narrative fairly boring, the characters unmemorable, and the pacing plodding at best. Yes, I know it's based on a historical event, but that doesn't excuse the sheer boredom this movie subjects a viewer too.

I liked it a lot but there was something that really buggered me: the lack of CGI hence the small scale of the battle (few planes, few ships, few people). I was always expecting the battle to start like "ok, this is only a skirmish" but no. I know the director didn't want to use CGI to be as real as it could it have been but for me it failed in replicating the sheer size of the battle.

¿es Dunkerque la mejor obra maestra de Christopher Nolan? ¿acaso merecía más el óscar a mejor película del 2017 en vez de la forma del agua? 
Pues bien, Dunkerque, es una OBRA MAESTRA. Ambientada en los años 40 en plena segunda guerra mundial, nos narra la ''operación dinamo'', la cual fue una misión de rescate, para sacar a casi 400.000 soldados ingleses de la ciudad francesa de Dunkerque, la cual se encontraba azotada por los alemanes. Lo más genial de esta película es: absolutamente todo; primero que  nada, Nolan nos narra la historia desde tres perspectivas distintas, un soldado que intenta escapar, tres civiles que en su pequeño barco pesquero intentarán rescatar de las aguas a la mayor cantidad de soldados, y un piloto de avión; es interesante cómo logra capturar una experiencia bélica vívida gracias a sus bien cuidados aspectos cómo lo son sus magistrales efectos de sonido o una fotografía con muy buenos planos secuencia; gracias a que es una película con escaso diálogo, permite a Nolan mostrarnos una historia en vez de contárnosla y aunque eso ya es toda una hazaña, no se compara con la osada realización al momento de recrear cada detalle, una de las cosas que hace que se sienta tan real cada momento bélico, es que el CGI(efectos visuales generados por computadora) es ausente, me atrevería a decir que todos los efectos especiales son reales, las decisiones tomadas en cuanto a utilizar réplicas de aviones y barcos REALES de la época, más el desafío de filmar en mar abierto y en el mismo lugar en el que ocurrieron los eventos reales, el diseño de los escenarios, vestuarios y otros elementos, hacen de esta un logro en cuanto a producción y dirección, y una obra visual y estéticamente significativa. El montaje es un punto verdaderamente fuerte en esta producción, cada corte es usado a favor de la trama (como en toda película), pero esta usa cada corte de cierta manera que no puedo describir con palabras... porque simplemente ha sabido extraerlas de mi boca para que sea usted el que se de cuenta de ello, solo diré que no había visto el poder del montaje tan bien usado desde pelis como "memento"(también de Christopher Nolan) o "seven: los siete pecados capitales"(de David Fincher), películas que también recomiendo  demasiado. Pasando a la parte interpretativa, todos se lucen muy bien en sus papeles, entre la cuantiosa cantidad de excelentes interpretaciones que aparecen en la cinta, destacaría la magistral interpretación de Cillian Murphy, que aunque su tiempo en pantalla es muy corto, hace un trabajo que está a la altura, no me puedo ir sin hablar también de las actuaciones de Mark Rylance, Jack Lowden, Fionn whitehead y Harry Styles. La banda sonora compuesta por el ganador del óscar, el gran Hans Zimmer, refuerza el suspenso y es verdaderamente intrigante. En síntesis, Dunkerque es una epopeya de emociones, detallada, realista y llena de suspenso. Para mí es la segunda mejor de Nolan solo por detrás de ''el origen'', y desde luego que merecía el óscar que le quitó ''la forma del agua'', que también estuvo súper buena, pero no a la altura de esta. 9/10

Christopher Nolan has always struck me as a very talented film-maker, and most of his films are ones that have impressed me a lot. Even weaker efforts, where his ambition can get in the way, have a good deal to admire. His films are all impeccably crafted technically, and often entertaining and thought-provoking, also knowing how to get good performances out of talented casts.

'Dunkirk' had me interested in it from the get go. Not just because Nolan was the director, though he is to me one of the "appreciated" directors than a personal favourite, and, while all his films range from decent to outstanding, again from personal opinion only 'Memento' is a film without faults, so like him and his films but don't consider them the best thing since sliced bread. There was also the involvement of Hans Zimmer, who has penned some great scores (both in his collaborations with Nolan, being a regular, and elsewhere) and a cast that includes Mark Rylance, Kenneth Branagh, Tom Hardy and Cillian Murphy. Plus 'Dunkirk' was based off one of the most disastrous events in British wartime history, actually cited by Winston Churchill as "a colossal military disaster".

Seeing 'Dunkirk', after hearing a lot of acclaim but also a lot of divisive opinions on both sides, there was a lot to admire about 'Dunkirk' but, although it is a visual, technical, audio and directorial masterpiece, it is not the triumph of film-making it could have been. As far as Nolan's films go for me it's a lesser effort, meaning often impressive but flawed where ambition gets in the way of execution, feel exactly the same way about 'Interstellar' which has similar strengths and flaws to 'Dunkirk'. Personally do feel strongly that regardless of how disappointing it would have been to others it is a long way from a 1/10 film, even if the film didn't do much for me it would have gotten a 4 at least from me.

Let's start with the strengths first. First off, 'Dunkirk' looks amazing, so far being one of the best-looking films of the year. Very evocatively designed, atmospherically lit and the cinematography is dazzling with some grit but also some audaciousness. Nolan's direction is often superb, especially in the very visceral spectacle, and on an audio level it is just as big a triumph. The sound is constant but didn't bother me, coming from somebody who can have hyper-sensitive hearing but is used to loud noises and high volume (necessary for the experience) when going to the cinema. If anything it added to the authenticity.

Hans Zimmer's score has garnered a lot of praise, acclaimed from most in part, but has had some dissenting opinions. Count me in as someone who loved it, there is an ominous quality but also a pathos and rousing bombast that enhances the pulsating heart-beat.

The action is often enthralling, and there is some nerve-shredding tension and some heart-wrenching emotional pathos (like in Cillian Murphy's performance). Loved the performances as well, the best coming from a quietly dignified and understated Mark Rylance who can say little and still speak volumes with just a small gesture, his eyes and his facial expressions. Kenneth Branagh's role is not a large one but he does make much of it. Nolan regulars Tom Hardy and Cillian Murphy command the screen effortlessly, Murphy's shell-shocked soldier in particular is genuinely moving. Was absolutely shocked in a good way at how good Fionn Whitehead's and Harry Styles (on paper an insane casting choice) feature film debuts were.

On the other hand, what makes 'Dunkirk' less than triumphant is that the characterisation, writing and story are on the messy side. Didn't mind the minimal dialogue and understood completely why it was done, did mind that the characters were underdeveloped and severely lacking in depth, one never gets to know them which is a shame because the acting is so good.

'Dunkirk' has been criticised for being emotionally cold and not getting enough into the horrors of war. Do agree with those criticisms actually. There are times actually where both actually come through, there is tension and suspense, there are some harrowing moments and some poignant ones, but we don't want moments, we want consistency. 'Dunkirk' is not horrifying or gut-wrenching enough (for war films it is fairly tame) and does lack consistent emotional investment.

Nolan could have done more with the historical side of things, it is a good thing that a good deal of people here have knowledge of the event but it can't be assumed that everybody knows about it or all the facts, nobody expects a history lesson but there was a missed opportunity in this regard. While being a technical and visual masterpiece, some of the editing is chaotic in places, as an epileptic it was just about bearable but still felt too much even for what it was trying to do. Lastly, while having a non-linear structure is not a bad thing (Nolan did it with 'Memento' and masterfully) how the three stories were told did get confused at times and it was hard keeping up with the constant back and forth.

So overall, less than triumphant but hardly disastrous. Often impressive but problematic. 6.5-7/10 Bethany Cox

While it may not be the best Nolan film ever, "Dunkirk" still stands as a very enjoyable and expertly crafted war movie that is a welcome addition into the genre. The acting was great and the action was thrilling. The cinematography throughout was captivating and the story mostly kept you hooked. I also loved how visually appealing the movie was and the dedication that was put into the making of it. The problem I have, however, is that the film tries to make itself unnecessarily more intelligent, where it tries to throw in a unique way of telling the story that just doesn't seem to work and makes the film sluggish at parts. While this has worked very well with other Nolan films in the past (Inception, Interstellar, Memento), "Dunkirk" didn't really need to feel as convoluted and hard to follow as it ended up being. Overall, this is still a very great film and a much more mature war film than others, but it still tries to reach much higher than it probably should've, and the film could've been much more simplified to make it easier to digest.

This movie was a gem to watch.  Three stories plied upon one event that happened at the beginning on World War Two at the beaches of Dunnkirk.  We get to see three heros of courage (the pilot, the boy (George), and the Admiral) as well as a good depiction of a regular private going through the day.  It struck me that this film was not so much about courage as it was about sacrifice.  The ending where we hear(as read) Churchill's address to the Bristish nation is equally compelling, and a message for world leaders of today.  The sacrifice of hero's is no small matter and Christopher Nolan does a wonderful job here of letting it play out.  There is no greater love than to lay down your life for your freinds is the motto shown here, and it will bring you to tears.  Great film.

Action-packed, compelling, and formatted in a chronologically creative way, this could possibly be the greatest war movie of all time. I would recommend reading about the history before watching, though, if you're not a history buff
I kept wanting the plot to emerge but it didn't. I pity the person who watches this who isn't aware of the historic facts because the circumstance is barely explained. At least it looked pretty.

One of the best movies ever made. I don't like all of Christopher Nolan's movies, but his interpretation and understanding of how to tell this amazing true story was a triumph. Hans Zimmer understood the point and ambience of the movie with his score. The obvious sequel would be a remake of The Battle of Britain. Please do it.

Timelines in a war movie could be highly dangerous to handle, but Nolan is known to be one of the greatest directors of all time! The sound quality is stunning, the scenography and cinematography are tremendously breathtaking! Highly recommended! My rating: 9/10
This has to be my 3rd favorite christopher nolan film behind the dark knight rises and the dark knight. It was very tense and the hans zimmer score was fabulous. Very good movie.

People may criticise the film for whatever reason, but Dunkirk is a masterful film that will be appreciated the more you watch it. I still consider The Dark Knight Nolan's Everest. But Dunkirk has climbed high
Pretty good. Only thing I didn't like was it was hard to follow.
It was better the second time I watched it.  Good, but idk to me...still not great.

Christopher Nolan displays DUNKIRK with little dialogue and visually exciting images. His past films have been spoiled with overexplaining the plot and premise. DUNKIRK breaks free of such flaws, with many moments being sparse of dialogue. The desperation of the situation is shown in a very convincing manner while also bringing very convincing performances to the screen. Suffocating sound mixing, editing, and soundtrack make the feeling of dread more prominent. The cinematography is impressive and vividly beautiful. Nolan and the production team prove you don't need a lengthy runtime to do so much so well.

Nolan proves he doesn't need a lengthy runtime to do so much so well: With awe-inducing setpieces, a tense soundtrack, fast-pacing, and Hoyte van Hotema's stunning cinematography, "Dunkirk" elevates the standard for the war genre of film.
It is a movie with a great climax and ending and amazing cinematography but it is slow meaning that nothing happens until 50 minutes in.
I didn't like it at all. It felt too fake, and as I'd only recently learned a lot about the two world wars, the film felt disrespectful. Maybe I was emotionally biased on this occasion.

The most boring most historically inaccurate account of the Dunkirk evacuation I've ever seen.  Completely disjointed storytelling.  Do yourself a favor and watch the 1958 movie about this battle.

A couple of really ridiculous scenes in this movie were (spoiler alert):
- a half dozen British soldiers aimlessly wandering around the town of Dunkirk picking up propaganda fliers dropped by the Nazis predictably get gunned down almost to a man.  There's a war on boys and you're surrounded.  Maybe you should act like it.
- Tom Hardy is a Spitfire pilot whose plane never seems to run out of ammunition.  He shoots down three German fighters and a couple of bombers before he finally runs out of fuel.  He shoots down another Me-109 after his engine quits and his Spitfire just glides and glides forever with the engine off and he still has time to manually crank down the landing gear and land on the beach!
- The scene where a British minesweeper is bombed by a German bomber shows the minesweeper anchored when it's supposed to be underway on its way back to England loaded with evacuees.  None of the bombed British ships takes any evasive action from any of the German bombers.

If there's only one Christopher Nolan movie you can watch, then it should be Dunkirk.
The suffocating and terror that filled the whole movie are the best thing I saw in that year.

Not much happens here. Very slow movie with very little to say. Its most prominent feature is the overly dramatic and ominous music that stands out in the excessive slow scenes with not much happening except soldiers shuffling about. Started skipping ahead after 30 minutes out of impatience. I thought this was at least a shocking reminder of the horrors of war but it fails to be even that. It's just bland and half-empty and mostly pointless. Same content could have easily been presented in a 1-hour cut, and it'd have been be easier to watch - less of a waste of time.

Also, it joins the likes of Transformers 2 and Snowpiercer etc. in being the victim of a certain psychopathology going around in Hollywood that makes their editors impoverish the colors of the movie and make them all revolve around Teal and Orange (many things that should be grey are actually greenish/teal, even white shirts have a teal hue to them; anything wooden or warm-color textile will be a shade of orange; hardly any blue or magenta or true red or true yellow to be found anywhere). I thought the Teal and Orange insanity might be dying out, but it seems not - Hollywood is still holding on to this idiocy.

I watched this on HBO, so I had complete control over the sound volume the whole time. I guess that nullified the most impressive part of the movie: the unnecessarily loud soundtrack (to where even some veterans commented that the movie might have been louder than the actual war). But the Industry can pat itself on the back, I guess: once again it has fabricated another "blockbuster" for itself, complete with paid-for favorable reviews and awards.

Absolutely magnificent in its gritty, realistic take on the true story of the Battle of Dunkirk. Hans Zimmer's score was utterly gripping and kept with the theme of time. The fact that it sounds more and more like a clock speeding up keeps you on the edge of your seat. Christopher Nolan delivers in everyway as always. The acting down to the minor roles are flawless. As a war movie, this movie is fine. But that's all I can give it. I can't help but get thrown out of the movie due to the films overall structure. The hopping from time to time and trying to decipher where things are happening chronologically is something that I'm not a huge fan of in movies in general. If done correct, in my eyes, it does add tension to a movie but, I felt that this movie did not do it well. The action is brutal and let you know the horrors of war. Having said that I feel that this movie could have done better if we actually were able to connect with a protagonist. I know that's not the point of this movie but, I think that would've worked better in my eyes.

Nor a focus on the rescued French soldiers who returned to the front.  Nearly crosses over into the realms of patriotic delusion, albeit the reality of the terror and fear is well done...Dunkirk was a rout and should be shown as such...the story is not Britain's alone.

Christopher Nolan sets a beautiful setting for what it was like for soldiers when this event occurred and tells the story in 3 parts so profoundly that it sticks together like hot glue. Atmosphere is what Nolan did best and it creates a sense of fear and stillness like non I've seen before. A must see, though my only criticism is that some ( and by some I mean 1 or 2) events are not entirely realistic, other than that, I beg you to see this.

I love WWII movies but I couldn’t get into this movie. One, the events are out of order which was confusing at times. Two, there’s very little dialogue which hinders character development. The only characters I found myself caring about were the father and son on the rescue boat. Which, upon reflection, were the characters that had the most dialogue. Still, I kept watching, hoping there would be some sort of payoff at the end and, while I suppose there was a small one, it was not one that made up for the two hours I had invested.

I really wanted to like this movie.  A slice of WWII history I knew little about.    But this just isn't presented well.   I didn't care about the characters. One of the best war movies I have ever seen

Dunkirk is a solid war film and a must-watch for any Nolan enthusiasts or war film purest, but for a Director who I had always said, "Christopher Nolan should make a World War 2 movie" and who had the perfect style of dark, gritty, and envelope-pushing material...I sure was let down by this movie. Upon first viewing, this movie can be needlessly confusing, which is nothing new for a Nolan film but where movies like Interstellar, Inception, or Memento can benefit from being a little confusing forcing the audience to figure it out themselves. But a war film like Dunkirk doesn't really benefit from this style of storytelling, it's a very suspenseful movie at times but loses all of that by not delivering on any consequences for the characters.
A absolutely stunning picture. Great use of sound design and mixing. The aerial footage is the best I've ever seen in a film. Accompanied by a beautiful score as well.

This is a fantastic war film. It sets out to give the viewer an accurate depiction of war, without gratuitous violence yet without whitewashing. It's not the war fought by heroes, but that of ordinary people. It captures the fear and suspense any ordinary man has, as the characters panic and hold on for dear life. And though some of the soldiers are not especially heroic (almost all except Tom Hardy's Farrier), you are left with an optimistic view for the future of mankind.

The individual characters are not very interesting, and the scope of the conflict is a bit jarring and lacking at times, but Christopher Nolan's jaw dropping use of practical effects and effectiveness at instilling suspense make Dunkirk a damn good movie

Dunkirk is an intermission from the Nolan sci-fi craziness of Interstellar, Inception, and Tenet in favour of a gripping addition to the period war film genre showing that this genre has some life in it yet. Critics constantly hound Nolan for his weak dialogue, and Dunkirk largely foregoes dialogue in favour of atmosphere to the film's benefit. The cast sink into their roles with efficacy. Who would have expected Branagh to star alongside Harry Styles? Nolan maintains the suspense throughout the entire process by delivering varied angles of the titular event, but mentions must go to Zimmer's score and Van Hoytema's cinematography. The director's practical effects and other trademarks for visual flair mean that Dunkirk always remains interesting and often excels through splendid cast, pacing, and ambition.
Best bloodless WWII film I've ever seen.

The level of tension and uneasiness which the ticking score not-so-quietly instills, combined with the amazing cinematography and Nolan-esque shifting time scenes made this an amazing movie experience in the cinema, whilst appreciating the mostly-non-CGI scenes which honestly radiate the effort which such a production would entail. Definitely a must watch!

This film was utterly absorbing and brilliant. Eschewing many of the standard war-film creative devices, "Dunkirk" delivers an immersive and realistic recreation of the 1940 Dunkirk evacuation of the British Expeditionary Force during the fall of France to the Nazi Blitzkrieg onslaught. From the very beginning of the film, the audience is thrown right into the fray of three storylines revolving around the evacuation and never truly allowed a rest. From dodging German bullets in the streets, cowering from dive-bombers on the beaches, and having ships sink from under us, to sailing to Dunkirk as a civilian volunteer, to flying a Spitfire fighter trying to protect the operation from German aircraft, the legend of Dunkirk is explored superbly. The immersion is very much helped by the film being shot at Dunkirk itself in the ground storyline, on open water for the sea storyline, and in the air with genuine World War II warbirds in the air storyline. There are some elements that detracted from the film, however. Director Christopher Nolan's aversion to CGI makes the filmed experience impeccable but forces the film to include a Dunkirk far too intact and clean than it was in real life, anachronistic ships, and too few men to truly resemble the real Dunkirk. Nonetheless, the film captures the terrifying and intense atmosphere excellently.

Three parallel stories, but none of them were really impressive. They also prefer to call the enemy as "the enemy" and not Germans! I was expecting a more impressive movie from such a sensitive subject.

Best artistic war movie.
A visual wonder!
This is a well shot WW1 movie and a gruesome story of heroism by every day citizens.
Not your common war movies. Intense psychological and suspenseful sequences. Another Nolan's time-bending masterpiece. Great cerebral flick but not too hard to piece the concept together.

I watch a film every day. I love films. It's been my thing since I was a kid. I remember when my mom bought me a DVD player for my bedroom when I was a teen, before most people had one in their living rooms. I say that because as a someone who loves film it's hard to explain to people the difference between films you like, films you love, and films you feel people have to see. I try not to waste people's time so I choose to mention the last category. Dunkirk is such a film. 

I need to carefully choose where to start. Why do I love this film? For starters there is how unusual it is. Upon watching this film you may not notice but this is one of the weirdest war movies ever made. Most war films have large battle sequences. Dunkirk is a character driven film set during a war. Think "Saving Private Ryan" (another film everyone must see,) but as a suspense thriller character piece where the war is outside the story. This film only wants you to care for the characters and not the action. It's weird, it's contradictory to studio thinking, and it's counter productive to any film maker looking to make money, but it is genius. 

The second thing I love is the time jumps. Upon first watching this film I didn't understand the time jumps and I didn't fully appreciate the film. It's actually three films. It's a film about a port which takes place during the course of a week. It's a film about a boat captain going to rescue troops which takes place during a day. Last, it's a film about a fighter pilot which takes place during an hour. This is Nolan. Every film Nolan manages to bend time and perplex his audience during at least a couple of sequences. This time he does it for the entire film. 

The last thing I love about this film is the characters and the themes. This isn't a war film that glorifies war. This isn't a film about heroes, even though there are a couple. This is a film that shows human beings in a situation where they will most likely die and it revels in the tension and passions that rise up from such a situation. This is one of the finest scripts ever filmed carried by some really great performances. Tom Hardy, Kenneth Branagh, even fucking Harry Styles is knocking it out of the park. This movie has some amazing acting in it and it's backed up by an amazing director with an amazing script. 

See this movie.

Dunkirk: Hope in the midst of loss.

This week I'll be taking a look at the stunning war film Dunkirk. Written and directed by Christopher Nolan, it features a large ensemble cast including Fionn Whitehead, Tom Glynn-Carney, Mark Rylance, Kenneth Branagh and Tom Hardy. The film recounts the historical events of the evacuation of the French town of Dunkirk after it had been surrounded by the German forces, trapping more than 400,000 British soldiers on the beaches. The narrative follows three different perspectives of the event; young soldiers trapped on the beach, one of the many civilian vessels that sailed toward Dunkirk on a rescue mission and two pilots trying to protect British ships from German Luftwaffe planes. The thing that struck me the most from the outset of this film is the incredible technical achievement that it is and especially in nonlinear visual storytelling. The editing especially is so precise, well paced and consistent that even though the three story lines are happening at different times and sometimes even overlap,  the flow of the narrative is never confusing or very hard to follow. Using barely any computer generated effects, there was no cheating on the structure and flow of the film's visuals and it presented a unique challenge to the editing team. Incorporating a complex element of balancing a weeks worth of action for the land, a day for the sea and an hour for the air added to the list of unique challenges bringing the film together would pose. Overall I was struck by how great the post production was on this film and how necessary being great was for the film to actually work. Making a film that breaks so many narrative rules and structures into a powerful yet still entertaining blockbuster is a feat that only spot on editing could have accomplished. Large and sweeping in scope while maintaining a sense of dire urgency and dread, the film deftly balances it's numerous elements to create a truly engrossing and moving experience. With time running out and losses getting heavier, the film portrays the situation that the men of Dunkirk had to go through by telling the fictional stories of three different groups and stirringly portrays their struggle to keep their courage and hope alive in the face of death.

Dunkirk creates it's tense and desperate setting by a relentless mix of pace, music and encompassing cinematography. Hans Zimmer provides a score that is jarring in many respects. As he did in Interstellar, Zimmer departs from the tropes common to the scores of the genre and definitely does not create a score that invokes the period. He instead provides a musical wall of low foreboding synthesized textures that conveys the feelings of desperation and fear in the soldiers with raw upfrontness. Also like Interstellar, the sheer weight and power of the score and the way Nolan often pushes it to the forefront might be a cause for a headache or simply feeling overwhelmed but this is definitely not because the music or score itself is bad but because it is doing precisely what it is meant to do. The job of the score is not always a pleasant one and while it is true that blending the music seamlessly with the background is usually the best way to convey the subliminal message music sends, sometimes to convey the intensity and overwhelming nature of the film one is watching, a score equally as intense and in your face is required. The gorgeous cinematography in the film also conveys the spirit of intensity while maintaining impressive visual quality. Filmed almost entirely on Imax cameras and without a single frame composed entirely digitally, the film team had their work cut out for them on this film but under the masterful leadership (and often camera handling) of cinematographer Hoyte van Hoytema, a sense of epic scale is achieved alongside the tensity of the action. The camera never cheats in this film because it never has anything to hide. So much was built practically and shot in camera that the action could be displayed as it is without having to cover things up with visual tricks. The feel of the camerawork places the audience in the story in a very immersive way while still maintaining a tight sense of dread. Shot in natural lighting and sometimes in very tight and constricting spaces, the cinematography is sometimes breathtaking, always wide in scope and captures tension in a unique and bold way. Another element that sets Dunkirk apart from a common war film is it's lack of dialogue and short runtime. Nolan expressed that from the very beginning of the film he wanted it to have a third act feel. To place the audience in the situation with the characters with no lead up or back story other than a few words of text on the screen and a leaflet falling from the sky. Dunkirk succeeds in it's gutsy attempt to create a film that is "all third act" with it's carefully crafted narrative acting as a strong skeleton for the rush of non-stop terror, action, movement and emotion that it pours out. With innovative tactics of yesteryear blended with distinctly original and modern storytelling and style, Dunkirk creates a visceral experience of a historic event that is to be revered and remembered as its subject matter should be.

The miracle of Dunkirk is an example of the human spirit to not lose hope in the face of death. Dunkirk was ultimately a defeat and yet at the same time a victory. This paradox is what makes the event so fascinating and makes the film so worthy of scrutiny. There is more to the hope in the soldiers and civilians of Dunkirk then just a belief that they will survive; there is also a more realistic hope, a more courageous hope that even if they face danger or death that they will be able to do some good with the situation. The people of England never thought to give up in the face of their defeat but put all of their efforts into an seemingly impossible task of enlisting hundreds of civilian ships to evacuate 300,000 men. Because of their stubborn hope they won a victory in the midst of their defeat. One may look at the situation as a whole and say that England simply eluded being annihilated and that no military advantage was gained in the event, for the people and the spirit of England, having their boys home safe was good enough and the film definitely portrays that side of the story. It doesn't pretend like Dunkirk was not a devastating loss, one of the final shots is of the pilot Farrier being taken prisoner by the Germans, but it does recognize and convey the spirit of Dunkirk and convey that spirit of unquenchable hope that was so important to the people of the time and is important for us who remember. However, the question in war is rarely "what can I do?" but "how can I do it?". In other words, the opportunity to do good and to be brave abounds but day to day choices become much more difficult. Risks still exist and every choice may cost you, another, or both of you your lives. In the film, in all three storylines, the main characters take every situation and try to do the most honorable thing they can. It doesn't always work out for the better for them, but others are affected and no deed goes without an outcome. In times of war, sticking to a true north may be the only way to keep one's head level and make the right choices, in the film, the characters stick to a code of honor that keeps them grounded while the horror of war swells around them. Another weighty topic the film addresses that the context of the story suggests is the value of lives over the strategic blow of a defeat. To clarify, I realize that escape was the only option at Dunkirk and that defeat was inevitable but at the end there is not a sense of defeat even though many British vehicles, supplies and lives were lost. The simple fact is that the leaders in England understood the real thing that needed saving and put all of its effort into making the best of a bad situation and in so doing made a bad situation good. The events of Dunkirk, and the film especially pose a dangerous battle between hope and desperation. Only by keeping hope alive was that good achieved. Near the beginning of the film the main character Tommy sits on the beach and observes a soldier that has given into despair and walks into the sea, drowning himself. The battle between hope and despair is so dire in wartime and especially in the situation of Dunkirk because despair is self destructive and speeds you on your way to death, while hope is a driving force to keep going through that fear into life. There can be no middle ground. Even with minimal character development, dialogue or time to reflect, Dunkirk still delivers much to be thought about afterwards and a lot of deep meaning to be unpacked.

One of the more brilliant aspects of this film is the way it deals with character. With barely time to remember their faces and not enough dialogue to remember their names, some may find it hard to empathise with their stories. However, this approach is entirely intentional and is not a product of lazy or poor writing. By giving the audience no background and minimal introduction to the numerous characters in the three storylines, I believe Nolan is doing two things, by not devoting any time to the introduction of his characters he is trying to make the possibility of their deaths much more believable. It is an almost universal understanding that if the main character dies he or she will die at the end. Anything before that doesn't hold any weight or stakes because the film is about them and usually has devoted so much time to their introduction and characterization. In Dunkirk, each man is simply another soldier among the thousands who may get lucky once, but might not get lucky again. The other thing that points to the intentionality of the overall "facelessness" of the main characters is that the reality is that Dunkirk is the story of thousands and thousands of individuals and to limit the narrative to focusing intently on a few would be to narrow the subject. Nolan portrays each place where Dunkirk was lived out, on the sea, in the air and on the beaches but by keeping his characters fictional and vague he is evoking the universality of the event and almost making it allegorical. Each character is almost meant to represent the entirety of their group and the experiences and feelings that each group had. Using this tactic, Nolan is attempting to not water down the events, but put them into an even more poignant spearhead. In this allegorical way each main character gives an example of the spirit of the film. George, Peter and Mr. Dawson all push faithfully on toward Dunkirk, saving two soldiers on the way and press on even when it seems pointless to do so. Tommy defends the life of the French Gibson when he is threatened to leave the rapidly sinking boat that hides them from the enemy. Even though he lied about his identity and even though Tommy knows that someone must leave the boat or they will all die, Tommy insists, risking his own life in the conflict. Farrier chooses to turn around and defend a ship full of fugitives even when his fuel is critically low and he ultimately gets captured on the beach but saves many lives because of his decision. Even Colonel Bolton makes a sacrifice of courage when he opts to stay on the beach and risks his life to oversee evacuating the French troops after the bulk of British forces had been evacuated. Each character represents the courage and spirit of the men at Dunkirk in a way that we might not remember their character specifically, but we will remember what they have done. 

Dunkirk is a riveting and relentless experience that is not only a testament to good filmmaking, but also a testament to a historic event that should never be forgotten. Nolans standards for filming as much as possible for real and his technically challenging script pushed the filmmakers to their limits in editing, sound design, production design, music, the whole works. The film puts thought provoking messages and themes into its narrative while still maintaining a fast pace and all the stylings of a thriller. Choosing more archetypal characters rather than his usual flawed central characters, Nolan quite intentionally disconnects the narrative from any specific person to create a more comprehensive account of the massive event that was Dunkirk. The film captures the spirit of what Dunkirk was with surprising clarity. The final scene speaks especially poignantly as Tommy reads Winston Churchill's address to the English people after their troops had been returned safely home. Churchill's famous speech where he promises "we will fight them on the beaches" holds an all new meaning as a message of hope and resolve plays over the aftermath of each storyline. In the midst of pain and tragedy, fear and terror, loss and pain, Dunkirk emerged as a beacon of hope for the war to come. As this film reminds us of that, it also stands as a beacon of great filmmaking, the innovation, massive amount of organization in its making mirror its subject matter and deliver a moving and awe inspiring experience.

MINOR SPOILER ALERT

Dunkirk is an exceptional film that deserves all the praise that it's received! It may be one of my favorite war films that I've seen, but to be frank, I haven't seen that many war movies, and I know that in this film is especially tame in terms of gore, but I kind of liked that because it forced you to focus more on everything that was happening and being felt by the soldiers, scared of death and full of suspense and awkward silence. The film really excelled in many different areas. I'll first comment on the acting, which was probably the most underrated element of this film. One must remember that these actors were given very little to work with, but they were able to communicate so much through body language and facial expressions. The jealousy of being unable to get on the boat, the need to remain calm under extreme pressure, the feelings of traumatic stress, etc., were all expressed very convincingly and only through a few lines of dialogue and everchanging faces. While it's definitely not the best acting ever, I do think it's worth mentioning because of how little the actors were given in the first place. Cinematography and editing were just beautiful, definitely the best parts of the film. I was surprised to find out that it did not win Best Cinematography at the Academy Awards, but I haven't seen Blade Runner 2049 so, what do I know? All I can say is that the scenes shot in the air and on the water were some of the most beautiful scenes I've seen yet (though I am saying this as someone relatively new to cinema). One scene in particular, where the one fighter's plane just glides along the beach of Dunkirk, and we see Dunkirk's landscape as the plane gently falls, seemed so realistic and breathtaking I thought I was in the plane myself! Needless to say, I was extremely impressed. In terms of direction and screenplay, I thought that Nolan did a great job. I liked his unique take with the film, and I thought that the absence of dialogue had Nolan's intended affect, which was to ultimately incite the same sense of fear and silent hope that the soldiers had experienced in the viewers. Nolan's direction is unconventional in that this is supposed to be an action-war type film, but what makes it work is the fact that it does have a decent amount of action and suspenseful scenes, yet everything has much more solemnity so the film is more grounded and realistic. There were very few things that I disliked about this film; the theme of nationalism sort of annoyed me because that's kind of why they were in the war in the first place, and at times the film could be a tad bit boring, though not as much as I expected it to be. Ultimately the reason why I decided not to give this film the full five stars is because it honestly didn't completely amaze me and it's definitely not something I'd casually watch again, but still, I'd recommend it to friends.
Not as good as the original . The uniforms too clean

Dunkirk is a combination of three narratives going on that end up merging together. The nonlinear storyline helped to add to the anxiety & uncertainty. I found it genuinely stressful from the opening to the closing sequence and there's so much that your senses are never even given a break. More like an experience of true horrors of war showing that war is not about some brave personalities with weapons. It's about nameless and faceless soldiers facing an existential crisis, the possibility of randomized death, and how they can either respond with despair or hope. Hans Zimmer's terrific use of sound also puts you right there in the middle of the war and some of the sound effects were so real that you couldn't help but feel as if you were right there which provides you an intense experience of death. Christopher Nolan shows again why he's an important phenomenon in films today. His work is experiential, his screenplay is more action than words. The class this man brought to movies is unmatched by any other filmmaker in recent times.
Amazingly creative storytelling but far from Nolan's best. Basically zero fun in this film which makes the relatively short run time critical.
Fun movie that my whole family enjoyed.
It's structure is both a blessing and a curse. Thankfully the film doesn't overstay its welcome and has plenty of tense and well crafted sequences.

Man, this movie is such an experience to watch. Christopher Nolan just knows how to make these wonderful stories with great atmosphere. The three individual plots are great enough, but how they meet up is just great. Another thing that is great is the action, which is probably accurate to what was happening at the time, which is nice. Speaking of facts, to my knowledge, the movie is pretty accurate. Also the cast is just great. Like dude, you were able to put Harry Styles into the movie and make it work. That's not suppose to happen!!! Also the big name stars do their job well as well. But there's one problem to this near flawless film, which is the characters. The actors playing these people are great, but the characters really aren't. Like they're not bad per se, just….forgettable. I literally watched this movie a hour ago and I don't remember any of the characters names, except for Georges, the only reason being that he dies in a weird way. Sure, you can have a great story, but none of it is going to matter if you don't have memorable characters, which Dunkirk doesn't have. Besides that, it was nominated for best picture for a reason. If you can deal with a movie with very little in the character department (like myself), then this has to be on the top of your list.
So boring, i don’t understand the hype it got

Honestly hard to follow and it jumps 
around everywhere, comes off cowardly as all they do is run, and the boat scene is underwhelming.... it was like 10-20 boats. Historically it was around 850 private boats. This movie missed the mark by a lot! Not really worth watching.
An effective 2 hour anxiety attack. Visually stunning and well-written, with one or two hitches in the pacing, Dunkirk is an uncomfortable pleasure to take in.

Dunkirk is an war action movie directed by Christopher Nolan and released in July 2017. The mains characters are Tommy(played by Fionn Whitehead) Peter(Tom Glynn-Carney) and Colonel Winnant(James D'Arcy). The movie takes place in Dunkirk during the Second World War. It tells the story of the evacuation of British and French troops under enemy's fire. This evacuation was a success with the help of civilians boats. The plot is a little bit difficult to understand because their is no explanations during the movie. Why have to guess were the movie take place, when. But this make the movie very unpredictable. After that, I would say that the movie is very absorbing. It's easy when you watch the movie to identified yourself to the characters because there is a lot of different personalities. The visual effects are very outstanding and make the movie even more realistic. This movie cost 150 M $ so it's an high budget movie. Photography is impressive. There is a lot of different filming technics used in the movie. The acting was very natural and realistic. Actors are really thinking like real terrified soldier doing everything do save there lives. The script is very realistic with a little part of inexplicable. It is also moving and spectacular. It's a real blockbuster. To conclude, I found this movie very realistic and absorbing. The story is complicated to understand but when you are in the movie it's really absorbing and you live every minute of the movie.
WOW! You truly feel the fear joy and sadness experienced by these heroes. I 100% recommend this movie

Dunkirk was a periodical piece retold by Christopher Nolan about the largest civilian mission to evacuate over 300,000 British soldiers surrounded on the coast of Dunkirk, France during WWII. I never know that it ever occurred where Churchill ordered his people to do whatever possible to try to help bring their troops home. They successfully saved their boys with their ambushes plan. The movie won Oscars for sound and film editing as well as sound mixing. The story was told from three view points all intertwined in one story. I just hated when they went from present to past to when the soldiers make it back to their hometown. The few lines in the script did not truly tell anything about the story, there was more action and less storyline to follow. The cast included Tom Hardy as a fighter pilot, Kenneth Branagh as the Commander, Cillian Murphy and Harry Styles. Overall it was a good movie with no plot that I can't see watching again.

'Dunkirk', as you'd expect given the director, is extremely well made. I particularly enjoyed how the film is shot, the sound editing and the score. It's a watchable story about an event from World War II.

I wouldn't, personally, say there's a standout cast performer. I don't mean that negatively, it's just more a film about a group of people rather than individuals - which I assume was the intention. There are still good performances, from the likes of Tom Glynn-Carney and Jack Lowden. It also features star names, including Tom Hardy, Cillian Murphy and Mark Rylance.

The music and how the sequences are crafted is what elevates this film up, while the pacing is almost spot on - they could easily have made this 2hr 15mins+, like most war films seem to do, but keeping it at around 1hr 47mins was a smart choice. I do still feel like it could've been greater, yet I still got entertainment from it.

Christopher Nolan es uno de los mejores directores del momento, y aquí podemos ver sus virtudes y también sus defectos.
 La película narra éste segmento de la historia donde unos desesperados soldados británicos, atrapados en las playas de Dunkirk, Francia esperan 2 posibles desenlaces, ser rescatados por sus aliados, o ser barridos por los alemanes. La película es un "bombardeo" constante de imágenes fascinantes; la película apenas nos da tiempo de entender lo que estamos viendo por su ritmo frenético y en algunos momentos se toma su tiempo para mostrarnos la majestuosidad del momento en cuestión. 
La idea del director creo es más mostrarnos el terror que se vive en una guerra más que darnos profundidad en cuanto a personajes, ya que éstos son sólo parte de algo superior en la mente de Christopher Nolan. 
Es una película de ésas que ya pocos se atreven a hacer por la generosidad visual que se muestra, el horror que uno cómo espectador vive al ver a éstos hombres combatir no sólo a un enemigo, sino a sus temores más personales. 
Una épica película de guerra que será reverenciada por muchos y menospreciada por otros tantos.

I first saw this in the cinema on an iMax screen, where the scale and sweep of the film is awe-inspiring and overwhelming. Conventional wisdom would suggest that revisiting it on my laptop would diminish it; and while it's true that the experience invokes less awe and wonder, the changed context reveals other strengths. Chief among these is a surprising intimacy which springs from the choice to mainly focus on a handful of characters; the relentless tension remains, but now we're drawn into the frightening, remarkable fellowship of people with names and faces living through previously unimaginable trauma, allowing me to emerge with a kind of thankfulness to individuals as opposed to nameless masses. 

The smaller screen also allows the emotion to sink in - something people often (misguidedly, in my view) say is missing from Nolan's films. We are drawn into these men's experiences of war; and whilst intense, violent trauma leaves little room for the outward expression of feelings, emotion is unmistakably there in the deaths and other losses, the relief on Kenneth Branagh's face as he gazes at the horizon to try to work out what he's seeing. - and at many other times. It also suggests to me the film may be touching on something around masculinity - or at least, the sort of masculinity war and its associated trauma forces men into; to push feelings down in order to survive. The implication, perhaps, that our models of masculinity are still in the shadow of two global conflicts and many other more localised ones; has the societal cost of what conflict does to combatants (so often men) and all affected by it truly been counted in how we expect men to be, and the implications of that for all manner of relationships? A question to think on.

Technically there remains so much to admire - the remarkable score, the sound-design and cinematography amongst them. I was also struck in a way I wasn't in the cinema by how often there is little in the way of sound emerging from the events on-screen - some shuffling boots of otherwise silent men, the ricochet of a bullet, the waves. This allows the sounds of conflict to have more power when they do arrive - and also enhances the intimacy; truly a triumph of sound-design. 

I was rewatching this with my cinema trip to see Tenet still quite fresh in my memory, and Dunkirk's tight structure, discipline and the relentless pace do show up Tenet's weaknesses. Dunkirk remains a triumph, however - telling the same story as the inferior Darkest Hour did, from a different perspective and without the same crass national myth-making that film indulged in. Of course, elements of the myths Britain continues to tell itself about Dunkirk and this war, in general, are still here in Nolan's film, but it does with more emotional honesty and resonance than The Darkest Hour ever comes close to achieving.

Tecnicamente impecável, mas o que é além disso?

Essa obra me causou uma pequena confusão mental. Por um lado, eu estava impressionado. A fotografia do filme é um tão impactante quanto um diamante refletido. A técnica de alternar as proporções funciona muito bem aqui, mesmo que seja mais aparente na Smart TV. A trilha sonora se encontra muito presente, o que pra mim é um ponto positivo. O cenário é absolutamente lindo, seja em alto mar, na terra ou no ar. O elenco tá bem definido, mesmo que o mesmo não tenha um peso muito grande aqui. Enfim, assistir essa obra em 4k HDR é uma experiencia unica.

O roteiro do filme está em outro nível. A compreensão de Nolan quanto a técnica narrativa vai além do esperado, e aqui, mais uma vez, ele prova isso e brinca com a linha do tempo para nos entregar uma experiencia mais impactante. O clímax, onde as três storylines se encontram é muito bem feita e conduzida. Porém, nem tudo são flores.

Apesar da minha agradável concepção aos aspectos técnicos, o filme não parece ter uma alma. Meu envolvimento emocional foi zero. O desenvolvimento dos personagens acontece, mas simplesmente não é o suficiente para criar uma ligação entre os mesmos e o publico. A trilha sonora passa a sensação de que mil e uma coisas estão acontecendo, ou que há algo grandioso para acontecer,  o problema é que essa tensão soa forçada, pois nada a altura da OST acontece, e você fica se perguntando "porque???"

O cenário, apesar de lindo, não aparenta ser de um filme de guerra. Os soldados não parecem cansados, e toda aquela situação não aprece tão ruim quanto o filme tenta nos enfiar "goela abaixo". Para uma total imersão, decidi rever o filme no fone de ouvido, sem legendas e com o áudio original. Porem eu não contava com uma trilha sonora tão alta. Na maioria das vezes, principalmente se tratando de compositores talentosos como Hans Zimmer, isso não me chateia, mas aqui todos os personagens fazem um esforço ENORME pra... sussurrar. Não sou fluente na língua inglesa, porém a dificuldade que tive pra entender as falas foi fora do normal. O filme já conta com poucas linhas de dialogo, e quando há, eu não as entendo.

No final das contas, assisti o filme mais uma vez, priorizando o máximo a imersão e qualidade  do mesmo, mas ainda assim não fui capaz de dizer o que essa historia veio para contar.

Edit: Depois de me esforçar muito, consegui entender o porque muitas pessoas amaram o filme. A atmosfera criada pelo Nolan é, talvez, inovadora. O vazio, a falta proposital de emoção, expressividade ou até personalidade provam o ponto niilista do filme. Eu fiquei um pouco confuso, pois a OST tecla muito no drama, que ao meu ver, não existe sem pre-requisitos. Porém, eu consigo sim compreender o porque esse filme é autentico em alguns aspectos, e isso merece sim seu reconhecimento - mesmo eu não tendo entrado no filme.

Áudio: English, no subtitles [6°]
Quality: 4K HDR

This film distinguishes itself from other war films in a very interesting way. I do not think we can really call it a war film. This film is not so much about the war, but mainly focuses on the soldiers who are just trying to survive. Every soldier for himself, because that is what it comes down to. The film does not depict, like most films, a fairly long time span, but rather a short moment. It also shows that all soldiers are living at the moment themselves. No one can control who dies or who is spared. There is no difference between rich and poor, smart and stupid. Every soldier is equal. The director reflects this by not focusing on the background stories of the soldiers, sometimes we don't even know the names of the characters. Anyone can die at any moment because of the unknown enemy. Christopher Nolan reflects this nicely by never showing the enemy. We only see the Germans at the last moment and there we only see a shadow. The interesting thing about the film is that we see the story from different perspectives: An ordinary soldier, a fighter pilot, a naval officer who arranges the crossing and even a family who is going to rescue stranded soldiers. The minimal use of special effects gives the film a very real feeling.
Except for a few moments of suspense, the rest just bored me. I love almost all of Nolan's movies and like the rest but this is one that will soon be forgotten and not watched on repeat.

As Saving Private Ryan was a war movie about the characters and succeeded as that, this movie is about a moment in history captured as it played out with no single or even group of characters to get to know on some deep emotional level. Instead, you know where they are and what they're going through, and you don't need to know anything else. Nolan is one of the best directors today for good reason, and the visuals in this movie are some of the best he's delivered. And his writing, as usual, is also incredible. It is less dialogue heavy than some of his other works and tells this story visually through a majority of it, and makes it work perfectly. There are three timelines being displayed at once which was a bit disorienting at first, but once you get how the story is playing out, it really makes the movie even better. The performances are wonderful, and very very real. I don't think any other war movie really puts you in the moment like this one. It's another masterpiece from a legendary filmmaker.

If you want to watch a good film, watch either Inception or Tenet if you want to watch a good Nolan film, or watch 1917, which was a very similar movie that was done WAY better. I understand people who like this movie, it wasn't that bad, but it wasn't for me. I LOVED 1917 though.

I am in awe of the filmmaking on display in Dunkirk. With only a 77 page script, Nolan was clearly rolling with the momentum, just as the entire picture feels like an increasing snowball running down the hill. The shots captured on camera with as few VFX shots as Nolan used in this film are remarkable.

Christopher Nolan's strong direction combined with Hoyte van Hoytema's outstanding cinematography make for a visceral depiction of the events at Dunkirk. Hans Zimmer's score coupled with Nolan's use of reaction and insert shots creates extremely intense and suspenseful sequences within this film. Nolan, once again, proves his fervor for non-linear story telling which can sometimes feel unnecessary in this film but overall doesn't hinder the plot too much. All the performances are very strong which just further adds to the sense of realism. Christopher Nolan has proven his ability to direct films with elements of action, sci-fi, drama, and even fantasy; you can now add war films to that list.
Even without an actual plot and not much talking, Dunkirk delivers a great war movie.
Dunkirk: Nolan’s dispostion is shown in full grand scale. With terrible acting, (shockingly bad) writing and dull characters, Dunkirk is fruitless filmmaking - and generally really damn boring.
Intense action combined with a realistic portrayal of what war is really like provides a captivating film, well filmed and edited with beautiful photography to put the cherry on top.

Dunkirk is one of the weakest war movies I have ever seen, and a big disappointment for a Nolan movie.

While it is plagued by boring scenes and unsympathetic characters,
the main problem is the absurd decision to make it PG-13.
This was an experiment to display the terror and anxiety of a war without any of the physical threats that are part of it.
And it failed miserably.

While a war movie doesn't necessarily need the gore effects of a "Hacksaw Ridge",

The plot and story line are disjointed. It's like Christopher Nolan and Emma Thomas wanted to imitate other films with loosely connected but separate story strands and a little diced up  chronology. Many segments are edited and cut short yet others drag out unnecessarily. The cast is pretty good with Mark Rylance and Kenneth Branagh holding the thing down while a younger cast mostly struggle under the awkward direction and video editing of the final cut. Cillian Murphy was an odd piece of the puzzle and could have been better portrayed by a younger actor.

The final 20 minutes builds a good climax and the errors of this project come together with a half decent finish. Dunkirk 2017 is a WWII period piece so all the ladies hand out cookies and tea if you can count the 60 seconds of female acting, yes it is a sausage party of a cast.

While Dunkirk is different from every other Christopher Nolan film, it also somehow manages to include many Christopher Nolan tropes that make his films special. although the film includes the same usual cast (minus Michael Caine), and includes a similar visual style, the structure and story of Dunkirk is what sets it apart. In some ways, this is good for Nolan, however, in a few more ways, it doesn't. As a start, it is important to point out a flaw with the characters in this film. It suffers the exact same problem that I faced with the Dark Knight Rises, Nolan can't seem to be able to pick one protagonist. This could have worked if it was done in a similar way as Pulp Fiction, telling multiple short stories that are non-linear, but all build into one storyline. On the other hand, Nolan decided to do a similar method, but to do it linearly. This makes it so we, as the audience, don't spend much time on one single character at one time. Although each scenario is different, both visually and structurally, it would have been nice to learn more about each of these characters, and why everything in the movie is so important. Everything just seems incredibly thrown together, and the timeline just doesn't quite fit. There are certain things that feel real in terms of time, for example, following the small British boat throughout the movie made the journey feel long, drawn out. However, there are other cases in which the timeline doesn't work at all, especially all of the soldiers on the beach. Every scene on the beach seems to just be more or less the same thing. There was a lot of room to build upon the importance of each troop on the beach, but the film mostly threw that away to value the overall entertainment more. Which, on that note, I should mention some of the good things about this movie, because it isn't all bad. As I said, the movie is a very engaging and entertaining watch. Although the timeline doesn't feel right, the way it is told keeps the tension of the film rising every second. This is accompanied by Hans Zimmer's brilliant score, using an auditory illusion to constantly build. The way the film looks is also a brilliant take, a usual Nolan staple. So, while there are things in Dunkirk I would prefer a different way, the entertainment value, visual style, and decent performances by the cast make it at the very least worth watching.
Storytelling at its finest.
Fantastic. Don't tell me it's as good as Saving Private Ryan or Letters from Iwo Jima though

The non-linear story-telling served absolutely no purpose other than to make the film seem "deeper" than it actually is. It's technically well-made, but there are no actual characters in this entire thing. You never get emotionally attached to anyone. I know the tense soundtrack throughout is supposed to bring a sense of urgency to what's happening, but that can't work if I simply don't care enough about any of the characters.

Two men run along a beach carrying a man on a stretcher. They are running to catch a ship which is casting off. For what seems like an eternity, the camera switches between the men, who seem to be getting nowhere, and the ship casting off. If you have been watching movies for the last 30 years  or so you know what is about to appear to happen. The ship will appear to cast off before the men can possibly reach it. But, the men will reach the ship in time. You are supposed to be amazed. If you find this kind of scene amazing, maybe you will like this movie. If, instead, you see the start of the scene and go "ffs, not this tired old trope again" it may not be for you.
Fundamentally this film is a series of events that like the beach running scene make absolutely no sense.
A battle rages on a street while a few 100 metres away soldiers lounge on a beach seemingly oblivious. A fisherman is able to instantly calculate the buoyancy of his bullet holed boat to within the weight of one man. A destroyer has a room inside it seemingly larger than the destroyer. I could go on.
At the time of watching, what I mostly thought about was how incredibly boring and long the movie was. It was a real effort to stay in the theatre to the finish.
The movie is vastly disconnected from reality.
Is the director satirising Hollywood movie conventions?
Is this meant to be some kind of nonsensical dream land reflecting the insanity of war?
Or is his perception of reality so utterly limited that he doesn't see how silly it is?
I don't know, but for me the resulting movie was hugely over-hyped and utterly boring.

Dunkirk is why IMAX theaters exist and why people buy giant widescreen televisions as this film is a feast for the eyes that the chef Christopher Nolan has been preparing his whole life to give to the audience. When I had heard a small radio spot about the film being screened for actual survivors of the retreat of the battle of Dunkirk I thought to myself "Nolan is so sure of his ability to bring authenticity to the big screen and pay homage to this time in history that he is willing to let those who were really there be the first judges." It feels like a dire retreat from start to finish and the stakes are only getting higher and higher as there is this ever-increasing sense of tension in the score of Dunkirk that keeps getting more intense as the film progresses. Murphy pulls off an extremely convincing victim of shellshock and very possibly PTSD as a soldier who is marooned on the lifeless skeleton of his former ship. I can ramble all night but at the end of the day, this is a fantastic war film.

Christoper Nolan's 2017 WWII entry is a well crafted, modern day classic that is able to capture the fear and humiliation that came during the retreat. While Nolan's insistence on practical effects ends up hurting this entry (the beaches feel empty for 400,000 men, there don't seem to be enough planes) he still delivers a dramatic piece that captures you. This movie differs in Nolan's usual style of long, dialogue heavy movies, where it's only 106 minutes and the characters hardly talk. But this allows the viewer to inject themselves into these characters rooting for each to make it out alive. Overall a great film that I would recommend to anyone.

Christopher Nolan‘s Dunkirk feels like World War II more than any film in memory. My dad was Army Air Corps and my Mum, Royal Air Force in the war. This film feels like their stories. 

The novel out-of-sequence narrative of the film subtly comes together and outlines an even deeper story of timelessness and eternity. 

Acting is first-rate and SFX are AMAZING! Everything looks real. Pacing lacks the pinball action common to other films that painfully try to be exciting. Dunkirk moves along evenly and smoothly...ike Time and Fate. 

This is cinema. This is a great film.

Dunkirk has that Nolan's plot-twist trademark but it's not as easily spotted, instead, it's all about timing in this movie, and how every scene, minute and hour in play rolls out, it starts a bit confusing but you get the hang of it, a truly captivating film about a particular episode of WWII.

Dunkirk occasionally starts to loses control of it's fast-paced narrative, and doesn't find anything particularly new about the nature of war, but it does renew it's age-old themes with a sense of downtrodden, hopeless urgency. It shows us the horrifying immediacy of wartime death in the way that Saving Private Ryan did, and is by turns disturbing, exhilarating, and occasionally powerful.

This movie was absolutely excellent. I think that the direction was extremely well done. Christopher Nolan's skills really shined in this one. However I think the lack of script left me wanting more. I understand the vision behind the movie of not giving the viewer a lot of context so they can add they're own fear and emotions to the characters; give the audience a chance to read between the lines and make assumptions but I wish we could've been given a little more words to help get us there. I feel like half of the time the only sounds were that of explosions and it made the movie extremely heavy. In a way that definitely helped to keep the tone and establish a consistent mood but I just feel like there were times where it would go into a bit of a lull and I would almost fall asleep because no one was doing or saying anything. Those times could've been filled in with a little bit of back story on something the characters went through to provide us with just the slightest bit of context and keep us invested in the movie throughout. Other than that I have no complaints. Acting was amazing, definitely was surprised by the addition of Harry Styles, but not disappointed in the slightest.
