While visually stunning, action packed, and very well acted this movie falls flat as it attempts to both show the broad story of the evacuation of Dunkirk while focusing on about eight different characters that are barely fleshed out. 
The movie is generally split between three different points of view; the beach of soldiers struggling to survive as they await evacuation, a plane squad coming to defend the soldiers, and a small boat coming to take as many soldiers as possible back to England. These different points of view are seemingly on slightly different timelines, meaning that you may see a plane crash happen from the pilot's perspective and then again 20 minutes later from the boat owner's perspective. These time shenanigans feel simply pointless and add nothing but confusion to the plot.
Another effect of the many different points of view is that no character is focused on nearly enough to be known by the audience. They all lack any unique personality traits or specific goals other than doing their jobs and/or not dying. This leaves many character actions feeling random and the danger that they are in no different to the danger of any other background character. For example, there is a scene in which our main soldier on the ground (who is in most posters of the movie) must escape a ship that has been hit by a torpedo, swimming in a sea of struggling soldiers and nurses our hero escapes through an open door that a friend of his opened. However the viewer am left thinking far less about his safety and far more about all those other helpless soldiers who are drowning and who our protagonist has just done nothing to help.
This lack of characterisation only becomes more and more apparent as the characters move from action scene to action scene, it being clear that the characters are really only vehicles for the audience to see all the different horrible ways people are dying. And while the lack of reason in the deaths of many soldiers may be intended as commentary on the lack of reason in war, the camera still focuses far more on the assigned "protagonists" of each point of view as if their lives matter more than those of anyone else on screen.
The sound design and music while technically well done becomes overbearing quickly as pounding music continues through almost every scene, creating a sense of impending danger whether or not there is any reason for there to be one. I personally also found it overly loud, which while realistic for a battlefield caused me to just cover my ears during many of the climactic scenes.
Overall Dunkirk is a disappointingly flat movie that I would not recommend to anyone except maybe a history buff or camera man.

I viewed this film obviously knowing the true historical events thinking how can it possibly be stretched into a near two hour runtime. The end result was a triumph and satisfaction from watching the best film of 2017 so far.
The film has three parallel time lines showing the evacuation of the beaches of Dunkirk from a ground perspective, an airborne perspective and from a sea perspective aboard one of the many small boats requisitioned by the Royal Navyto rescue some of the hundreds of thousands of stranded Allied (well British in this operation) on the beaches of the small French coastal town of Dunkirk. 
The casting is good. It includes Kenneth Branagh as a Royal Navy officer overseeing the evacuation from a rickety mole at Dunkirk.
Mark Rylance (Bridge Of Spies) portrays the sailor of one of the small boats with probably the best performance of the film.
Tom Hardy flies a Spitfire above with aerial photography that puts Top Gun to shame.
Even the boyband One Direction ex member Harry Styles puts in a good performance in his acting debut.
As mentioned the photography is excellent making full use of the IMAX cameras the film used especially in the aerial shots.
Directing plaudits go to Christopher Nolan of Batman Begins fame.
Before you know it the near two hour film elapsed and I was glued to the screen from beginning to end. 
The sound was deafening. Be it gunfire or the soundtrack of Hans Zimmer.
A worthy addition to the war film genre.
With the recent Brexit political events in the United Kingdom one cannot but feel some national pride in the evacuation even if it was a defeat really as the Nazi army had our boys hemmed in on the beaches.

The first part of the movie was about one soldier attempting to get away from the beach. After several unsuccessful attempts to get on a ship he got on and it sunk. Three British fighter planes took forever to get in position to protect the troops and ships. This movie is highly overrated. The directors attempts to make it PG 13 significantly reduced realistic action scenes. Too bad I was not tired because it would be easy to take a nap. Don't waste you time or money with this movie.

I saw Dunkirk 4 days ago, but I really wanted to sit on the experience and not review it until I fully understood what Christopher Nolan was going for. This isn't your typical war movie, neither it terms of structure or execution. But it is how you'd expect Christopher Nolan to tackle a war epic; with a non-linear structure, tightly written and directed scenes, and one heck of a mind-blowing score from Hans Zimmer. It's far from the easiest film to dissect, but the experience is undeniably moving.

Being a massive Christopher Nolan fan, I came into Dunkirk with high expectations and a ton of curiosity of how Nolan would treat a true story. This is the first film of is that attempts to take real-life events and present his own depiction. Unsurprisingly, the thing I love most about Dunkirk is Nolan's direction. Quite often war films look at the big picture (rightfully so), covering events from each side and telling in-depth stories about politics and survival. There's nothing wrong with those approaches, but the fact that Nolan takes a massive-scale approach to Dunkirk visually, when in reality the film is just about soldiers trying to survive on one particular beach, makes it all the more impressive. When you get past the fact that there's little dialogue and character development, there's plenty to love about Dunkirk.

Nolan's films all have those defining visual moments, as he often loves to have his non-linear structure be used to its full effect and use the multiple story angles to create a few epic moments. Think Inception, when the "dream is collapsing" and there's 3 different layers of dreams all coalescing at the same time. Dunkirk uses that same approach for pretty much the entire movie, The Mole (beach), The Sea, and The Air. The editing can be frustrating the first time around, as it was for me, especially when you really just want to learn more about each of these characters if they expect us to care at all. Jumping viewpoints turns out to be exactly the way this film should be structured. In reality, none of these soldiers would have time to tell each other their respected backgrounds or life stories, they're just trying to survive. I thought Nolan handled this beautifully.

Complementing the rapid editing is yet another terrific Hans Zimmer score. Nolan said in an interview that he gave Zimmer a recording of a ticking clock to give him an idea as to how he wanted the tone of the score to feel. Well, Zimmer took that to heart as that ticking clock is literally heard throughout the film. I love all of the Zimmer-Nolan collaborations, and Dunkirk is no exception. In fact, Zimmer's score could almost be considered more of an impactful character than the real characters themselves. There aren't many composers that can match the intensity that Nolan wants behind and in front of the camera, but Zimmer definitely does.

From Tom Hardy's almost dialogue-less performance, to the breathtaking cinematography from Hoyte van Hoytema, and the incredible work done by Hans Zimmer, Dunkirk is a film which sees Christopher Nolan at the top of his craft. It's the shortest film of his since 'Following' but it may very well be his most emotionally effective film, and that's without developing any characters. Every year I'm hoping to see movies that change the way cinema is made and viewed, Nolan is one of the few directors that constantly break new ground in Hollywood. As much as Dunkirk isn't what I thought it would be, I can't ask for anything more than for him to reinvent the genre.

Watching this movie (on a subject of great interest to me) has reinforced my belief that the professional "movie critic press corps" has been bought off by big money Hollywood studios. Not only did I learn nothing new about what actually happened historically, the movie failed on just about every level I can think of. Is it too much to ask that a good story have a beginning, a middle, and an end? I don't know much about the Producer/Director/Writer (did I leave anything out?), but I suspect he suffers from "Orson Welles Syndrome", wherein a talented director achieves early success with one big film, is acclaimed as a genius, and loses sight of of his craft, in pursuit of more acclaim. (Directors like Quentin Tarantino and David Lynch come to mind.)

To be picked apart for the colour of the water or the actor's hair cuts is simply pedantic - yet truly blind.

As an avid fan of Christopher Nolan's films, I too was deeply disappointed by Dunkirk. 

Trust me, I get the whole "artsy" thing Nolan was going for here. Very rarely does a director of his caliber even entertain the idea of attempting to make a film like this. It was beautifully shot, expertly crafted, the music was fantastic, etc; cinematography-wise it's very much a Nolan movie. 

However, the disjointed story line, the loudness (saw this in IMAX), the unintelligible dialogue (however little there was), the pacing, it was all just so jarring, and scrambled, and un-engaging, IMO. 

I just didn't care about any of the characters, I kept getting distracted by the constant cutting-away to different story lines (whenever I would try to digest what I just saw, something entirely different was going on and try as I might I just couldn't keep up), and 90% of the dialogue sounded mumbled to me.  

In the end, I left feeling frustrated and like I just witnessed a great big giant mess, a beautiful one, but a mess nonetheless. 

I give it a C+; wasted talent, imo.

Christopher Nolan only makes good movies, and Dunkirk is no exception. I just didn't get it, there's so much to the story that wasn't told, there's no scale to just how much of a disaster Dunkirk was. You end up hating the characters because there's nothing to them. The theory that the "timeline is all over to enhance the confusion of war" just adds to the lack of story or anything really happening. You end up watching the same scenes played out 10 times, just from slightly different angles. I have never left a cinema disappointed before. Watching Dunkirk changed that

The film is breathtaking and should be seen on the big screen. The directing is masterful but the characters are uninteresting and the writing isn't the best. Though that might've been the point, the film just missed the mark for me.
Very poorly done.  Not realistic at all.

Sure to be quickly forgotten, this drawn out, empty film is like one who uses many words to say nothing. It's a void on film; an anti-movie. Made to gather acclaim and awards and box office dollars before being laid to rest in the realm of the unmemorable.

See this if you cannot distinguish art from entertainment, and wish to be misled. If your viewing experience is narrow, you might convince yourself this film is less superficial.

Very overrated movie. I typically love war movies, especially ww2 movies, but this missed the ball in many ways. You don't get to know any of the "characters", so you don't care about them. Acting is fine, but there's also very little dialogue throughout the movie. Overall, I wouldn't watch again
Nolan manages to put his own spin on the war movie that keeps the tension high for its entire runtime.

OMG. This movie sucks. It way to loud, for one. The score is not something to be proud of. There is NO dialogue. There is NO plot. I don't feel sad for George, because his death was stupid. And where were all the other boats? Why did this movie follow unheroic cowards (ahem, Harry Styles and Fionn Whitehead)? Why did Tom Hardy's character land in Nazi territory when he could have flown in circles until he reached HIS territory? Why, Chris Nolan? WHY?! The Dark Knight sucked, too, by the way.
Awesome movie. Loved it from beginning to end.
Not great. Probably the worst Christopher Nolan has ever done. And it was still decent.

I was very disappointed in this movie. Just lots of scenes jumbled together without any pattern, which made it difficult to follow. Very little coherent dialogue. There was no real story told. Also, the music was loud & unending throughout the entire movie.
Uniquely screenplayed - you will like it.
Intense, powerful, moving, well paced. Music is incredibly deep and rhythmic.
Wow!  GREAT movie about one of the most pivotal events in history.  Very moving and creative.
I have been to a lot of movies but this has got to be the worst movie I have ever been to. The movie was way too long and very boring.
Nolan at it again with another 5 star movie.
Amazing sound, great picture. Definitely a spin from whatever Nolan has done before, this movie centers in placing in the beach rather than expanding on the characters
Best film of the year so far. Exhilarating.

Dunkirk could be my favorite Nolan film, it's definitely the most rewatch able. While it's lacks in story and characters it makes up for in suspense and drama with these mostly nameless characters. You feel the will to live and get off that beach in every scene with the soldiers. The best parts of the movie though are the score and the cinematography which carry the film. The ticking clock was a great touch too the score.

Great visuals, clear and passionate storytelling! Christopher Nolan is clearly a visionary auteur. There is a sense of tension that runs the duration of the movie and adds real stakes to the characters. 

Hans Zimmer's score is authentic, daring, and tense. 

The only aspects that deserve critique is the sound design. As with some of Nolan's films, it is often hard to understand or hear dialogue. Characters that have an obstruction over their mouth (mask, etc.) lose articulation in their lines and it's hard to follow story points. 

Additionally, there was a lack of representation from women and diverse cultures. Something that's hard to ignore in 2017.

An overwhelmingly visceral and immersive portrait of the rescue mission that happened at Dunkirk. Nolan jettisons the clever-clever noodlings of his previous epics and simply focuses on a handful of individual acts of very great bravery - at sea and in the air. Several sequences are almost unbearably intense. Technically, a total triumph - it also benefits from a brace of extremely good performances. A major return to form after Interstellar.

Terrible. Felt little connection to any of the characters, there were a lot of ups and downs, but there was very little done to build the desperation & chaos I was expecting to be portrayed. Everything felt so disconnected. Score was good though. There's better war movies out there, skip jumping on the Nolan bandwagon here. (Hacksaw Ridge if you haven't seen it!)
would of rather watched a dumpster fire

I don't get the hype. There is no character development. No reason to care about which ones live and die. No context into what was going on like everybody is supposed to know what happened 70 years ago. You couldn't understand what little was said because of either the background noise or the soundtrack drowned out the voices.  If you go to a movie to be entertained then stay away.

This is an awful piece of work. It is an insult to all of those who endured at Dunkirk with no feeling for the enormity of the debacle. While I can understand a certain lack of historical accuracy, there should be a good story line, good character development and some historical perspective. Instead we were served up with a very thin gruel of some uniformed men standing on a beach in good order, waiting for ships. The director tried compensating for his lack of substance by cranking up the volume on the special effects, and the result was a noisy, bland work that should be relegated to the garbage dump.
Eh, too slow at times and had too many scenes where the actors say nothing and anxious music plays instead
Very long and boring movie. Yes I guess, this is intense, it tells about what is war... I went to watch it when I heard that the ratings were so good, it was very disappointing!

Brilliant war film.

Many could complain that there is no character development but I feel that is perfect for a movie like this. We believe we need a main character with some cliche backstory and the ability to not be killed or damaged, but this movie depicts a real perspective of a solider as they try to fight a losing battle.

The intertwining stories are both a positive and a negative. It's nice to see how all the stories meet up as they take place in a week, a day and an hour before all linking. The disadvantage is being able to foresee some results of what happens, which can ruin the tension of the solid soundtrack by Zimmer.

Those looking for bloodshed and gore will be disappointed at this movie as it doesn't show any, but in my opinion, gore cheapens the moment and ruins the somber atmosphere created. Action movie junkies should also look elsewhere you won't have a Rambo type mount a jeep and fly straight into a German plan only to perform a superhero landing.

This movie all round is a great interpretation by Nolan of the battle of Dunkirk and strongly recommend to anyone who is looking for a worthwhile war film or a film in general for that matter.

I'm very surprised at this movie. I love military/war films and I love Nolan but this movie was really boring. I appreciate what they were trying to do: create a suspenseful anxious experience. The music combined with the pacing does that. But overall it's a very ho-hum experience and I would never recommend this to anybody.
really enjoyed this movie :)
So very realistic.  Makes you realize what those soldiers went through and endured.
Every single frame of this film is amazing.
Just wasn't feeling it.  Slow.  Not particularly captivating.  Plodded along.  Can't recommend.
No story to follow. Boring

Maybe the most tense war movie ever. Even without blood, gore or even a tangible enemy, the claustrophobia and helplessness make you squirm in your seat. The sound design is probably the best I have heard in any movie. every buller makes your gut twist, every dive-bomber your heart stop. Nolans best work so far.
Loved it.  The beginning timelines are a bit confusing, but other than that, a great war movie!
Too loud and too long. Zimmer's soundtrack overpowers the film.

Extremely overrated. No plot, character development, blood, context - just endless shots of water, air, and Tom Hardy in a fighter mask. Sometimes impressive as a purely visual spectacle, it nevertheless left me utterly cold and indifferent. You almost wish the Germans would roll in and start shooting just so something would happen.

This movie is based on a really great story, but that is not evident in the film.  It almost seems as if it was a 4 hour movie edited down to nothing but the war scenes.  The actual story is missing.  Disappointed.

One of the worst movies I've ever seen. Poorly constructed story, never had enough time with one character to get to know, or attached to them. The timeline was all over the place, very confusing. I am normally a huge fan of true stories as well as war stories but I was left disappointed with this flick. Not sure how it's getting the ratings that it is...?! I seriously contemplated walking out.

Choppy plot. It, mostly, follows 3 timelines. One takes 3 days, one 1 day, the last takes 1 hour. They are interleaved. It doesn't work.
Tension is supposed to build. It doesn't.
Some parts just don't make sense. One ship's compartment is at least 20 feet above the water line, but when the ship is hit the compartment fills with water long before the ship sinks. Also, a boat is used by the Germans for small arms target practice, some bullets hit 2 or 3 feet below the waterline blowing holes in the hull.
Saw it with my adult son. He says he saw a container ship in the background.
Not cruel but realistic war.
great special effects but confusing as to when certain storylines where taking place.  Better editing needed.  If not for that, this movie would be perfect.
95 min anxiety attack
One of Christopher Nolans best films. Storytelling at its finest.
Dumkirk... should've left this movie on the beach
Intense from start to finish. Sounds and looks great, fantastic movie,

Flat and weak throughout, plot holes and an unconvincing beach scene make this film hideously overstated
a couple of good sequences make it watchable but it really isn't the masterpiece that everyone claims it was wanting to be
Impressively crafted, most immersive, and emotional film.

Quite a few of the professional film critics use the word 'immersion' meaning engrossed; absorbed completely when reviewing this movie. That's exactly what happened to me. One hour 46 minutes later, I came up for air. 
 
It's important to remember, though, that the director covers events three times: on the land; on the sea; and in the air.

The action is often repeated. We see some episodes from the air, then from the viewpoint of those in the rescue boats, and sometimes, through the eyes of those on the land. If you're not aware of this before you see the movie, the continuity could be confusing. 

Excellent cinematography, riveting story-line; and appropriate music.
One of the best war movies ever very emotional
Possibly Nolan's best film to date.  Suspenseful from start to finish, Dunkirk will have you on the edge of your seat.

A very disjointed story. With dark scenes it's hard to tell who is who sometimes and since the stories overlap it became confusing. Great acting and cinematography , but weak on plot and compelling stories. I found myself only caring about the civilian family in the boat.

This story had 70 years to be made into a movie, and we got this.

Where to begin? Let's start with it is easily the worst "big-budget WW2 film" in history. Where was the budget even spent in this movie? I learned more reading about Dunkirk on Wikipedia than this movie taught me.

Also, HUGE criticism here: WAS THE DIRECTOR TRYING TO GIVE HIS VIEWERS SEIZURES WITH THE NON-STOP HORROR/THRILLER-FILM LOUD AND INTENSE MUSIC?!?! 

I would NEVER recommend this film to an older person, the music is absolutely horrendous and unrelenting. 

There was not a single battle scene in the entire movie, and you did not see a German (with the exception of about 3 German aircraft TOTAL throughout the movie). This movie should be retitled, because it does not show even a shred of Dunkirk in it's entirety. The movie was about a bunch of British military guys disregarding rules/orders and doing anything they can to get on an evacuation ship before it was their turn to do so. 

Also, spoiler alert, in the movie there is a pilot who seems to be flying in the air for a VERY long time (he had 50 gallons of gas left BEFORE the civilian ships arrived, and somehow he landed on the beach at Dunkirk AFTER the Germans has taken over the area and the soldiers had been evacuated).

WOW - I'd like to know what the director and producers were taking when they made this one.

It makes no sense how this movie can be rated so highly. 

Don't watch this movie and hope to see heroes and a lot of inspiring scenes - you will see very little of that. 

Also, to all of those people who initially believed the movie "dissed" France:
You are totally wrong, my perception of this movie was that France was given more credit than the British! The movie made several mentions of the French holding the lines while the British evacuated, and the movie did seem to make a point that without the French Dunkirk would have been different.
Nolan knocks it out of the park yet again!! the score is perfectly tense, every moment feels like it matters. great war movie.
Best war movie I've seen
dunkirk more like dumpirk

Dunkirk asks far too much of movie goers. It both expects audiences to know the history of the famous evacuation and also to follow it on THREE DIFFERENT TIMELINES. Seriously to the Nolans: How about a plot that stays on one and only one timeline.  The triplicate timelines -- a week before the final Tom Hardy burn the place scene, a few hours before it and one hour before it -- make the movie seem rife with continuity errors. Unless you are ready to bone up on The Blitzkrieg, "Der Halt", and why Hitler's Wehrmacht decided not to knock Great Britain out of the war, expect a confusing hour and three quarters. Even then, know that this is another story told on three different timelines.  I feel like waiting for the DVD to come out so I can see each of the timelines in chronological order, ala the Momento DVD
No es una película convencional de guerra, apuesta por las emociones y el realismo, te sientes en la guerra, sientes la escasez, cada detalle, es simplemente asombrosa
Great movie! They do a wonderful job of showing how impactful and harsh war is

This is my absolute favourite war film. It's refreshing not sitting through another Hollywood loosely based on true events war film. I see ppl complaining there no character backstory so they find it hard to sympathize or care about character or find its confusing. Well I'll hold your hand through this. Dunkirk was real and a very historically accurate movie and the subject is the story, not like most Hollywood war films that need the same recycled lame unbelievable backstories to make u sympathize with the character to move the plot forward. Is it really that hard to care or have sympathy for thousands of young men some still in their teens dying or going through that hell. Next time I suggest stay at home and watch red dawn, if that's what you think war movies should be like.

Dunkirk was a masterpiece. But too big for little minds

Weirdly made movie with inflated ratings. The beach they were stranded on appeared to be getting attacked here and there by a couple of rogue crop dusters instead of the German army. If it wasn't for the stunning visual effects, it would be riding the line of a B rated movie. Way overated.
it was probably just the theater I was at but my ears felt like death after watching this film

I was expecting an emotionally moving war movie. You know, the kind where you root for the good guys because you hate the bad guys. The kind where there's actually back story so we care about the characters as they fight.  the kind of movie that establishes real characters and motivations. Instead, I get a beautifully photographed film that expects nothing from me and gives nothing  in which I am to be invested.  It was a waste of money.

What a disastrous film. The most egregious of the errors is that the filmmakers completely failed to convey the context and historical significance of Dunkirk. They created some dramatic scenes of ships sinking and soldiers drowning, but there was no continuous storyline or meaningful characters to follow. Overall, this was a big disappointment.
No explanation of who organized the relief flotilla.  Also couldn't understand the dialogue among the British soldiers.  A greart story told in a disjointed manner.

The fog of war turned into a morass of contorted plots and sub-plots. It was turgid and ungripping at any level. A boring and lack-lustre war film of the lowest category. Characters wooden and dazed and the entire historical context went AWOL. But, then again, who cares about representing facts in an historical account of war.
One of the worst war films ever produce. The only star is for the special effects, which weren't even that special really. Don't bother with this tosh!
I'll be thinking about this movie for days.  I already want to see it again.
The worste war movie I've seen.

It's clear that some people have difficulty in following this superb movie, and are so desperate for dialogue to present them with the story on a plate, and for 'character development' to enable them to achieve any kind of empathy with the key characters.

In fact, a clear storyline runs through this movie from beginning to end. Three young soldiers, two Brits and one French (spoiler) trying everything they can go escape Dunkirk, surrounded by a cleverly crafted and inspiring multiple timeline series of events going on around them.

It is not a documentary, and it's not a traditional hero war movie. It is an attack on the senses that you either sit back and absorb (which most people have), or you decide early on that you're not going to like it because it's too difficult to understand, and you should have gone to see Bridget Jones instead.

The lack of CGI to create hundreds of boats and multiple thousands of soldiers should be celebrated, not criticised. It allowed you to focus on detailed events and experiences of the key characters.

Another superb Nolan presentation.

The time-spatial setup is brilliant, and Nolan manages to pack in a lot of human feeling and close-up human experience in a movie with relatively little in the way of close relationships.  There is a lot of transient human interaction without there being much overdone human drama, if that makes sense.
Lol2 I know ok oi88i8lpitiful Ki8ki2n3n bb3 n3kkj nb koo ok k m9m k mmm k h k m9m l mmmm iiok w
Its tough to pull off something different in this genre.  Nolan managed to do so.  He was able to express how the nation helped save the nation...there was no single hero.  So well done
This movie was amazing. It had amazingly my scenes and the the dogfights made my heart skip a little
Overrated. Good, but forgettable.

Modern classic. A story of true heroism, and a touching representation of "we're all in this together." The airplanes coming down with that overwhelming sound makes us feel the soldiers' fear. The sense of care and "having each other's back," really moved me. Easily the best war film since saving private Ryan.
It's a well made film but very hard to watch. Not really entertainment, more documentary.  Not as difficult as Schindler's List but still uncomfortable.

This was a terrible movie (except for the special effects)  The story was disjointed and the characters were not clearly defined.  It was all fighting and scenes of war carnage.  If you see the trailer you have seen it all!!
I loved the cinematography and the same incident viewed from different characters' viewpoints but the battle noises were far too loud.

This isn't a movie, it's an art film. Not your typical war flick. It's beautifully shot with minimal dialogue so you become wholly immersed in the vast scenery and visual tension. 

The soundtrack was a tad too manipulative for my tastes, but overall...a simple yet stunningly beautiful film.

Someday said that the plot of most movies can be reduced to one idea - they need to get home - a safe place away from harm and Dunkirk is a perfect example of that thought.  Nolan broke Dunkirk down into three intersecting parts and along with the sometimes indecipherable dialogue, made the movie confusing at best.  But any movie that has one of my holy trinity of actors Mark Rylance (along with Bill Nighy and Jeff Bridges) in it starts with an automatic 100%.  Was Tom Hardy really in it? God save the Brits!  (8-5-17)
Bounced around too much and did not spend enough time developing or completing some of the story lines...
good telling of a part of Dunkirk

Very disappointing depiction of the events at Dunkirk.  It was a good movie but certainly not a great movie. From the reviews and hype I really was expecting at least a very good movie.  My  wife's reaction was the same as mine.... disappointment.
Nolan master piece, emotionally satisfying epic which you need to watch on the big screen.
Very good and intense. Wondered why there were so few planes and fighting though.

Amazingly poor film.  Depicts the British soldier as weak sniveling cowards and dumb as a rock.  The end scene of the heroic pilot best describes the movie.  The pilot pushes on knowing he will run out of fuel and does.  As he glides from low altitude toward shore, somehow he shoots down a bomber, but then must land.  It is daylight and he is shown gliding over his own troops.  Then he is shown landing AT NIGHT on a German infested beach - dumb pilot - magic plane.

If you are over 23 and think good movie making is more that loud noise, special effects and loooong expressions of awe, then get your entertainment elsewhere.  This thing was not just bad, it was awful.

After the balls-to-the-wall boredom of 'The Dark Knight Rises,' and the scientifically ambitious episode of La Virgen de Guadalupe known as 'Interstellar;' Christopher Nolan demonstrates he is unable to balance bombastic action, inner conflict and character development. It is a well-intentioned tribute to the ones that gave their lives fighting for freedom. Magnificent sky shots and real battleships don't count for real drama, though.

Another cinematic tour de force from Nolan.  Not a perfect film, or even his best,  but a visceral, unnerving look into the vagaries of war, of decisions that may or may not preserve your life.  Beautifully constructed, with multiple stories/viewpoints, each with a different time frame, a week on the beach (and trying to get off it), a day in a boat trying to save the troops, and an hour in the air, each with their own slow times, each with their harrowing moments of panic.  Absolutely worth seeing in the theaters.

Hardly any story, more of a pictorial representation of what it looked like at Dunkirk.  They tried to weave together different timelines into a single point.  Myself and my wife said it was confusing and seemed unnecessary.  One scene on a boat it's night, cut to a plane and its a mid day dog fight..... we both whispered "huh?", I sorta wondered if it was a blooper/mis edit.  The airplanes and aerial scenes were fantastic, but overall, it was meh.
Jesus Christ this was intense.
An excellent movie, with an even better cast. The way the storyline was constructed keeps the audience on their toes.
Horrible noise that is suspenseful but annoying
Awful movie, story line very hard to follow.
Very boring movie.  Couldn't wait until it was over.
Really excellent, saw it in Imax

I was physically, and emotionally exhausted from the pure intensity provided by this film. The score is comparable to greats like Halloween and Psycho. It takes a little time to realize how the timeline is situated, but as you do, it adds to the excitement and raw emotion of the film. The action starts instantly and breaks in the tension are few, and far between.This was by far the best experience I've ever had in a movie theater. I can't say that this is my new favorite movie, but its definitely in the discussion. Worth paying to see it in theaters, and I very rarely feel like thats the case.
Terrible movie, no dialog. Boring as all get out. Waste of miney

Very intense movie, worth the watch. Fell short for me, maybe I had to high of expectations? I've been seeing the movie trailer for over a year and was so stoked. It's a movie you will watch several times to catch things, you won't catch the first time. But they could of even go farther into the war, and even get more realistic and grab everybody attention to how it was like in the war.
Truly disappointing garbage.

Three loosely related stories (air/sea/land activity) with little character development (who are these people and what are their backgrounds and how they came to be in their situationss) and an annoying habit of jumping from one activity to another (particularly in the air battles which are too chopped up and distributed throughout the movie).  This is no "Saving Private Ryan" or "Band of Brothers" or "Fury".

Very different of a movie, for the first half I kept waiting for the "movie" to finally start, then I finally figured out what kind of "movie" it wanted to be and then I liked it a lot Better. Not much dialog, plot, names, or storyline. But it takes you into where not many movies really take their audience.

Pros
+ Direction
+ Beautiful Cinematography by Hoyte von Hoytema
+ Excellent Sound Design of the gunshots, explosions and Spitfire planes
+ Practical Effects
+ Intense, Heartpounding Soundtrack by the great Hans Zimmer
+ The Whole Experience of Survival
+ The Dog fights in the air
+ Powerful Ending

Cons
- Lack of Character Development
- Pacing of 'The Sea' chapter

My rating - 8.6/10 or A-
Zero character development, terrible dialogue and overall a terrible movie.   A great story that could have made a great movie but absolutely ruined by the terrible storytelling.
The movie was great visually. The plot and character development was lacking.

If you're making a film that focuses on certain characters, regardless of the situation taking place, a viewer would at least like to know about the character.

"Dunkirk" thrusts the viewer into a situation; a dire situation that obviously was HELL for those involved in this historical event. Following essentially 3 characters around, it's hard to root for any of them when you have no context to anything. I couldn't name one character - there was just 'soldier guy', 'boat guy', and 'pilot guy'. Without saying much, the way the movie's edited too makes it certainly interesting, but weird as well. 

While a technical masterpiece in terms of cinematography, directing, music (best soundtrack I've heard this year), sound, and choreography - Dunkirk is essentially a re-enactment, not a 'movie' per-say. Judging it on a re-enactment, it's a masterpiece. As a movie...not so much.
Christopher Nolan delivers yet another Superb Film

This is by far the single worst movie I have watched in a long, long while. Amateur actors, lousy acting, dialogues that could have been written by primary school students, zero suspense. Obviously, the director also did not bother to get military or other expert advice, otherwise incomprehensible the foolish arrangements and totally unrealistic scenes. The dead of Dunkirk are turning in their graves.
this is fantastic movie.
As a film can't really knock it - its intense, pretty riveting, pretty cinematic. Not so comfortable with some of the political themes.

Overrated.  Saw in IMAX. Painfully loud and could not hear half of the dialogue.
Movie is badly cut- keeps moving back and forth from scene to scene for no good reason.  Does not identify the enemy as German.
The bravery and heroism of the British soldiers was understated.  Churchill's greatest speech was read in part by a soldier on the train.  This movie is a dis-service.  It does show Dunkirk, but greatly understates its importance- the outcome of the war was changed by the miracle of Dunkirk.  
ALSO- of historical interest-- the  800 King's "daughters" who were the mothers of Quebec (http://www.cbc.ca/2017/canadathestoryofus/most-french-canadians-are-descended-from-these-800-women-1.4029699) came from the Dieppe and Dunkirk area.

Besides the clever opening scenes, perhaps just misses the magic touches of a Spielberg in terms of dramatic intensity. Relentlessly determined not to glorify war in general and these events in particular, you will still feel in awe of how nearly 300,00 troops managed to be rescued.
quite disappointed. from acting to special effect like someone made it on commodere 64

Nolan's Dunkirk shows how a well-crafted war movie doesn't need to display the graphic violence of a  war nor the dramatic character development, while keeping the audience immersed throughout the whole movie and making you feel the tension of a historic event. Great cinematography by Van Hoytema and one of Nolan's best work as of today.
An edge of your seat glimpse into the horrors of war.  It wasn't necessarily about the heroes but the survivors that could have been anyone's son, brother or friend.

Tried to be too funny and many parts were not funny but were stupid. The villain was not evil or scary, he tried to be funny and was promoted as likable, this is not a formula for a good movie. I felt I waisted my time on this, much worse then precious Spider man movies. I wont see the sequel of there is one. Should be rated 60 percent not 90. This is a C minus movie, definitely not an A movie. Aimed at teenagers not adults.

Served up te drama and desolation in buckets, but. Missed the drama of the the long rearguard actions, the fighting scenes with spitfires, weak. Fuel consumption calculations, what was that about? A spitfire does about 3gpm so saying there's 15gallons of fuel left whilst flying over Dunkirk, then going into combat .... no sense. The water landings........ don't even go there, dreadful.  The ship sinkings saved the day for me and this film.
Signature Nolan style of storytelling, but, I expect the scene will be greater.
Absolutely awesome. Its not fast paced (at least for me) but really builds well on its early scenes to release a very emotive ending. Again, absolutely awesome.

Dunkirk, as a movie, really wants to do justice to the evacuation of 300,000 Allied soldiers during World War 2.  Instead, with no introduction it roars headlong into a mashup of three characters experiences of the event.  The film totally fails to capture the scale of the evacuation as you only see a few hundred soldiers on the beach, and a few RAF aircraft in the sky.  From a visceral standpoint the movie works, capturing the desperation of the moment.  But Dunkirk truly fails to tell the story of this pivotal moment in WW2, and that's a missed opportunity. If you had no idea of this event from 1940, you'd have little more understanding of it after watching this movie.  Being shot in IMAX the cinematography is excellent and it was entertaining in that regard.  Nonetheless I would have preferred to see the movie explain more of how Dunkirk happened, and what impact it had in WW2.
A little silent, especially at the beginning, but after that the images and music tells the story by themselves.

The Acting is good as well as the cinematography but I felt the 1958 Dunkirk showed a much better scope of what happen, including the beach scene which grasped what real film & photos took on those horrible days of retreating to Britain!

Terrible, and a horrendous disservice to those who served!  No character development, no story explanation and just because you turn up the music doesn't mean we're going to feel something for characters we know nothing about.  In relation to the importance of this moment in time, this movie is an abomination.  I'm actually upset by how bad it was.  I hope no one who lived through that has to see this lifeless portrayal.
The score should not carry a movie. Also needed a lot more exposition. A scene would drag on and then the next would have too many jumpy cuts.
well made movie keeps you watching

Although there is a lack of character development; Dunkirk is certainly a spectacle to behold, and is definitely worth the price of admission. The sights and sounds are immersive and pulse pounding. Christopher Nolan does not disappoint with this WW2 Survival story.
Amazing film. Not a lot said but that's what makes it so good.

Nobody really has a name....which would have been fine except you never get a sense of each character's personality-- nothing.  SPOILERS . I was afraid I wasn't going to be able to tell the soldiers on the beach apart. The gas masks cover so much of the group of pilots faces, it was hard to tell which one of them died. The only set of people you sort of get to "know" is ONE SET of people on ONE RESCUE BOAT out of all the rescue boats that set out from England. I almost left before it was over. I spoke to people outside. I wasn't alone. In fact, I think there was a sigh of relief it over from the entire theater. This movie is cruising on Nolan's reputation.  If people watch this at home once its available for streaming, they'll hate it. The only way to get through this is to be trapped in a dark theater.
People who enjoy movies that are disjointed and have minimal dialogue will love this movie.
if only i was a war movie buff... probably would have appreciated the effort a bit more!

What the flying eff bs movie was that? I watched this garbage movie based on rotten tomatoes review and I don't get why it's rated so high. I get this movie has historical significance, and war sucks, and all the horrible things that happen in but holy eff how can you review a movie based on feelings? What a croc! A few hundred soldiers on the beach representing 300,000? Three German airplanes representing hundreds of planes?  A few dozen old boats representing thousands? This movie was beautifully shot with a moving score, but was completely lacking any character or story development. By the end of the film I couldn't even provide a name of a character. Besides having a general concern for characters because they're human beings, I didn't care what happened to these people simply because I didn't know them.

I was looking forward to this movie, and I wanted to like it. But I was disappointed. I hove historical movies, and war movies in particular. This is a story that I was thrilled to see portrayed in movie form. But in the end, in my opinion, this movie tried to be more of an art film / prestige movie than tell the story in question.

First, the good:
- Visually, the movie is very well done in my opinion. The sets, and backdrops and naval scenes and dogfights are all very nicely filmed / rendered, and they meld together very well.
- The acting was good in most respects as well.

Why was I disappointed? (WARNING: SPOILERS):
- The confusing time jumps - I see no reason why we had to follow the story from three different perspectives that happened over three different time periods. I don't think this added anything to the story except confusion. I went into the movie knowing that the story was broken down in this way, so I was ready for the possible confusion, and even so I did not like it. A family came into the move late and sat behind me. I felt bad for them because if you missed the first few minutes when the movie sort-of explained the time differences, then it must have been very confusing indeed.
- The constant (and I mean CONSTANT) background mood music - From beginning to end there was a bed of ambient mood music. I found this distracting and a little insulting. It seemed to me that the movie makers were trying to trick me into following their mood expectations instead of telling a good story and letting me decide where my moods should be. It also felt like they were artificially trying to constantly raise the tension level through the whole movie.
- A few other story elements that I didn't feel were accurate (technicalities, really) -
   The scenes felt desolate and forgotten. I would think that the greatest military evacuation in history would feel a little more crowded. They mentioned that the Royal Navy and RAF could only spare a few ships and planes, so that had some credibility. But as I understand it, hundreds of small vessels took place in the final evacuation. In the movie, the main civilian vessel we followed seemed to travel completely alone across an empty English Channel, and the largest group of civilian vessels the movie portrayed seemed to be about two dozen. I was expecting to see a lot more German planes and British 'little ships'. I felt like this movie was portraying some small sideshow forgotten battle rather than the end of a MAJOR phase of the largest war in human history. Maybe the movie is technically accurate, but I didn't buy it.
   Were Spitfires designed as gliders? - As the movie was coming to a climax, a Spitfire interceptor ran out of fuel in mid-air, but then proceeded to glide for a very, very long time. I simply didn't believe it. It seemed like the pilot could have glided back to England for as long as he was cruising back and forth over the Dunkirk beach. Again, this may have been technically accurate and might happen under optimal conditions, but I really didn't like this.

Conclusion:
I don't regret paying to see Dunkirk at the movie theater. But the combination of jumping back and forth in time, and the constant music bed made Dunkirk feel to me more like an hour-and-a-half theatrical preview of a longer movie - a very long highlight reel. I won't spend any more money on this movie. If I play this movie again, it will be muted so I won't be annoyed by an unwanted, constant soundtrack and can just enjoy some wonderfully executed visuals.

no no no no NO ! cinematography and special effects is the only thing I appreciated . Where is the blood,  and flying body parts? the movie is very predictable.  but hey there is not much dialogue. #nomyfavorite.

Also, harry styles (a man who has been full of surprises this year, with his good debut album) gives us a gripping performance. Well done Nolan, because I needed something to wash the images of the emoji movie out of my brain.

The cinematography, soundtrack, editing and direction were faultless. See it on the biggest screen you can.

Dunkirk is fictional story based on a true event that occurred on the beaches Dunkirk, France in May 1940. Written and directed by Christopher Nolan this movie wastes no time from the opening scenes with the sounds of planes and bombs. The action is great and feels real in the sky and on the ground. The film score by Hans Zimmer is amazing using his mastery of shepard tones to really drive the intensity. But if you go in looking for character building and development don't! This movie is a story of survival and courage and not about the soldiers families back home. I walked out of this movie not knowing the characters past but empathizing with them and their present situation. This movie wins at really putting you in the driver's seat and making you think how would you have reacted in this situation. I give Dunkirk an A.

Director Christopher Nolan manages to evoke an emotional response that I haven't felt since Ridley Scott's Alien. Nolan's clever use of sound design jars the audience into the action. Dunkirk is a white knuckled, fear coaster ride. I felt concern, urgency, and fear for the soldiers portrayed in this film. It wastes no time setting up the premise. This is a different war movie then what you may be used to. It doesn't dive into the lives of individual soldiers. There aren't any babies being kissed, or girlfriends hugged goodbye. After watching the movie, I realized that I couldn't even name a single character. That's not a bad thing. Nolan makes it clear that the focus of this film is on the event of Dunkirk. Nothing more, nothing less. For some, this may be a turn off as there aren't really any characters to relate with. There aren't any emotional sub plots to follow. This was strictly - Dunkirk. These are the soldiers trapped, and the German are coming to kill them. The movie showcases the realism of war; Not all stories end in happy endings. During war, soldiers die alone, in the dark, confused, and/or unaware. The creative use of editing at one point early in the movie makes a lightbulb click in your head, "Ohhh so that's what's happening." Honestly, the main gripe I had with this movie was that it was hard to understand what someone was saying at times (heavy English accents). I'm a southern boy from Texas, and picking up on full sentences was near impossible for me. I'm not sure if others had this problem, probably not! This is a must see on the big screen, and even more of an absolute buy for home theaters.

Despite the critical acclaim of this film, I found it dis-jointed.  Everything happened around the same spot but there were scenes overlapping in foggy daylight, dark of night, sunny day, back and forth with no attention to continuity.  The script was thin, and even when words were spoken it was often hard to understand the various UK accents. It was a "war" film yet it looked more like an Abercrombie and Fitch ad from GQ.  ALL the men were nice looking with really amazing hair.  The call for actors must have been "Must we a white male model between 20-30 with thick longish hair on top."  It consumed my attention.   Yes, I give Christopher Nolan and his cinematographer credit for some amazing shots--on the beach, in the sky, ships capsizing, men awaiting bombs, etc.  And of the several stories being told, the father and his son using their personal boat to help rescue soldiers was my favorite.  But nevertheless I wish I had seen another movie like Baby Driver or The Big Sick instead.

I was very surprised after having seen the film and checking online that everyone thought the movie was good. Despite the story's basis on an important historical event, the movie in itself was weak and relies more on the audience's relation to the actual event.

I have to admit that I was surprised to see so many positive reviews from the critics. Although the acting on the whole was very good I never got the impression of the true magnitude of this event. Additionally there were other flaws that disturbed me. The channel at that point is only 20 some miles wide yet the filmmaker would have us believe it was night on one side of the channel and daytime on the other. Well over 300,000 troops were saved by the evacuation yet I never had the feeling that more than a few thousand were ever endangered. Finally, thousands of small ships composing a small armada were involved in the evacuation, yet the movie gave me the feeling that maybe a medium sized yacht club came to the troops' rescue. I'm glad I saw the movie but I have to say I was disappointed.

A war film that deals with the war without the Hollywood glow and veneer that plagues far too many efforts of recent years and is actually, pleasingly, devoid of any "for the sake of it" gore and blood. Although that doesn't mean that it shirks away from the horror of conflict in any way.

'Dunkirk' deals with the evacuation of the British Expeditionary Force from France in 1940, after a disastrous British and French campaign to defeat the German Army on French soil, initiated by the former's declaration of war on the latter eight months previously. The British and French Armies (plus others like the Belgians) proved unable to deal with the Germans as they steamrolled through France in just six weeks. Something that proved impossible to do in the whole of WWI.

None of that history is really needed to enjoy the film although I feel, like with most war films, a certain understanding is useful (if somewhat unnecessary) to flesh out the events on the screen. But all one needs to know here is that the Allies have been defeated and the British are looking for a way out. The miles and miles of beaches at Dunkirk fortuitously proved to be it.

Christopher Nolan's film does extremely well to capture the dejected spirits of the men as they trickle down through the beachfront property to the sandy shoreline and form orderly (and terribly British) queues, while they patiently wait for a transport (any transport) to arrive and take them back to Blighty. The images of these queues are matched by period photographs and that attentiveness is what makes 'Dunkirk' a great success, at least the in the "Mole" section of the film, which is one of three timelines that the story is split across. "The Mole" (another name for a pier) takes place over the course of the week, whereas "The Air" is over one hour and "The Sea" is a day's journey. All sections are intertwined in a back and forth timeline, with the The Air being the weakest contribution.

"The Mole" unfolds largely from the viewpoint of a British soldier, an unnamed private, ably handled by Fionn Whitehead. Whitehead does well to capture the fear, confusion, dread and humiliation of the average "Tommy" in a largely "dialogue-less" role. Something that isn't easy to do. He acts as our eyes as he passively observes the situations and people who make up the souls trying to escape the portion of the beach he finds himself on. The Mole is the meat of the film upon which the other two sections are hung and contains the more harrowing of scenes. These are chilling scenes of men drowning in steel hulls as the ship they're stranded on becomes their horribly echoey tomb.

"The Sea" deals with the "little armada" of civilian boats that was requisitioned by the Royal Navy, because they didn't want to commit the bulk of the Navy to the rescue mission. It focuses on pleasure boater, Mr. Dawson, his son Peter and his friend George, who take it upon themselves to head to Dunkirk to see if they can aid the evacuation. This is based on true accounts of hundreds of boat owners who sailed south in the last days of May 1940 in an admirable, if foolhardy, crusade of sorts. Mild mannered Mr. Dawson is very well played by Mark Rylance who's understated performance contrasts with the horrors unfolding in the water around his little boat.

"The Air" focuses on a Spitfire sortie across the channel and their task to deal with the Luftwaffe attacks on the evacuation effort. Tom Hardy is second in a vic of three, lead vocally by Michael Caine. This section is laudable for its use of period aircraft, in the case of the Spitfire MkI and does well to get a post war Spanish made Buchon into the air to act as a Bf109E. Elsewhere there's also a post war Spanish Heinkel playing its part as a target for Hardy's far too good pilot. It's Hardy's unrealistic ability to destroy everything with a Balkenkreuz on it that forms the only real mis-step in the film. Also on a bad note is the film's portrayal of the Germans, who act as suicidal maniacs. While the film went to great lengths to get details correct, it's depiction of Luftwaffe tactics is a mess. 109's linger in turning fights with Spitfires and the film's only German bomber goes around on a bombing run, practically offering themselves as targets. Anyone who's familiar with the air war in WWII will be rolling their eyes, which is a shame because the filmmakers get so much correct elsewhere.

However, the above criticisms will only be spotted by a handful of people and while it knocks points off, it doesn't destroy the film altogether. It's still hard not to be disappointed about Hardy's "Greatest Spitfire Pilot of all Time" caricature.

Another criticism would be the lack of use of CGI to augment to air battles. Although some CGI was used to enhance the Stuka remote control models. While I believe Nolan's refusal to do a sweeping vista of a beach full of hundreds of thousands of men was a wise one (as there were never that number on any of the beaches at one time), the limited air war feels extremely anemic. It's correct that the Luftwaffe confined its attacks to mere pin prick harassment, in lieu of an all out attempt to destroy the BEF, but it's doubtful that any Heinkel crew would be flying into enemy territory alone as is depicted in the film. Those scenes are, of course, victims of the lack of physically available aircraft. But, they could easily have been fleshed out with computer generated ones to inject a bit more realism. I believe there could have been a balance attempted, instead of a flat out refusal.

Elsewhere, Nolan correctly refuses to make the film reliant on an "characters". The fact of the matter being that in real military units, the men rarely got to know one another very well. Men were transferred in and out of units, killed, wounded and captured, that you tended not to know anybody for too long. It would have been a mistake to make the film a squad based cliche with the accompanying Screen Writing 101 "characters", that so many war films do. While this can be troublesome for some viewers, I found it to be another feather in its cap. A cap which possesses quite a large number of feathers, it has to be said. Another of which is Hans Zimmer's spectacular, yet wholly unassuming score. Almost totally devoid of bombast, it's low bass pounding does wonders to increase the sense of dread and tension of the scenes unfolding on the screen. It's an expert example of what a cinematic score should do. It aids the film, without overwhelming it. In one or two places, it swells to unconvincing heights, such as its pinching of Elgar's 'Nimrod', as Hardy lands his out of fuel Spitfire on the beach. But, 99% of the time it aural support is absolutely bang on.

Despite its shortcomings, 'Dunkirk' is a war film that will largely please people who have studied the war, as I have for more years than I'll mention here. It's emotional, without being forced. It's horrifying in places, without being obsessed about it. It's reasonably factual, without being dull. For me, it joins a small number of war films that can be called great and Christopher Nolan et al deserve all the praise they get.

a typical nolan movie but with different storyline. Can't be compared to his past movies. To top it off Hans Zimmer music has made the movie where it is. This movie will keep you to your feet as a typical nolan movie does Cinematography is 5. Storyline is 4

A huge fan of many of Christopher Nolan's movies, walking out of the theater this evening left me feeling only one thing. Confused.

This movie was bad.  I truly cannot understand how Dunkirk received such high accolades.

The only notion which really saved Dunkirk was the general public interest in the WWII time frame and the political feat of this escape.  Dunkirk offered no real plot or direction besides the outcome that is known history. Character development was extremely limited. It's almost as if Nolan chose this way on purpose because he did not want viewers to connect to any of these characters on any level. This movie explained nothing of the actual Dunkirk event and failed to capture me in almost every way.  It left me anxious and distracted, not knowing how to feel about the movie in a large, more general sense.  The consistent, busy scenes which lasted from start to finish in Dunkirk offered a shallow, hollow attempt that this movie was exciting and thrilling. Rather, this was a noisy, fast movie with no real identity that piggy backed off this historical event.
A film that feels like a two hour panic attack, in a good way, depicting various points of view, alongside immersive action scenes and solid performances.

This is visually amazing, hands down one of the best looking movies I have seen. If all of the effects were practical my gosh I know where the budget was. I watched it in a tight theatre and it was very loud and it made me realize how amazing sound effects could be. The soundtrack was very subdued and a little forgettable. My friend pointed out the lack of gore, and I have a suspect that they had literally no budget for gore if the effects were all practical. Honestly I didn't care about the gore, I didn't need a Saving Private Ryan situation, but a little would've been nice. The plot was a little scattered, I know it's a historical film, and they couldn't take as many artistic liberties as one could take with a war film. It all came together in the end and it was nice. If I could give a quarter star I would but I don't think it's deserving of 4.5 stars (unfortunately).

A missed opportunity to tell a compelling story. Instead a disjointed montage is presented, without background or or historical context beyond the audiences must bring themselves. Not even a nod as to how such a dramatic situation was created. 800 boats came to evacuate the British soldiers instead of the 8 depicted by the director. 
Save the time it will take to watch this scrambles of a film to read up on the events. You will gain a grteater understanding understanding and enjoy it more.
Powerful visual, gripping reality, intense plot and structure, and emotionally inspiring.

I don't understand the high rating on this film. It's the first film I've actually wanted to walk out on. Hardly any dialogue, didn't develop any characters were you felt any emotional attachment and extremely slow/boring. Could have been shortened into half an hour really. Very disappointing as I expected a lot more due to the cast.

It's just about watchable, but only just. I can't work out how you can make a film based around a major war, actively ignore any sort of character development, fail to establish the scope of the situation, underuse VFX to your detriment and over rely on sound and music so much it should be called 'Hans Zimmers Dunkirk', and still be lauded as a genius. Ive loved Nolan's films in the past, but there are literally hundreds of stronger war time films than this. Christopher Nolan is arguably the most technically proficient director  in the game.  From one film to the next, he ceaselessly pushes the boundaries of his craft, insisting upon large format cameras, actual film, and ever more complicated shots.

As a result--technically speaking--'Dunkirk' meets or exceeds every expectation.  The expansive beach landscapes, claustrophobic interior settings, and countless practical effects all lend a sense of heightened realism to this historical drama.

Yet, it's the story itself that lacks the intensity Nolan was aiming for.  The three vantage point structure detracts from the overall immersion into the film.  Cillian Murphy's character is both confounding and frustratingly hollow.  And there is a fair amount of repetitiveness to the plot.   

It should be noted that Hans Zimmer's score is nothing short of remarkable and serves as a much need thread of consistency throughout the film.  However, when history has its say, 'Dunkirk' will likely reside on a lesser tier of Nolan's filmography.
Very slow, little character development. Almost cringe representation of air to air combat.

Excellent film - if you already have some background knowledge. I thoroughly enjoyed it, but I can understand the negative reviews. The editing is sublime (or confusing if you missed the 3 subtitles at the start), the script does everything needed of it (obviously the writer wasn't paid per word), and it is a survival story with a lot of war thrown in.

Dunkirk 15/70mm BFI IMAX. Films should be events, and this certainly is. Compare it to Masters of Cinema greats: Wellman's Wings, Lang's M, L'Aubier's L'Argent and so on. Every great film can survive as a silent. Dunkirk's sparse dialogue allows it to stand tall. Gripping, enveloping, jaw-dropping, awe-inspiring. Think skydiving footage in Moonraker, the opening plane heist in Dark Knight Rises and multiply it a hundred times. No CGI. No shortcuts. Real film making. Admirable and far reaching. 

A shorter film than normal for Nolan, presumably because of the size of the projector. Five miles of massive film strips. Bits of debris trapped in the camera gate made me think oh no I'm going to see this all the time now. But they disappeared from cut to cut, only raising my appreciation of Nolan's achievement. Yes, I love this film.

It could do with a few extra scenes, setting off from the English coast, maybe more loading of soldiers, but they'd only soften the film's impact, and you can fill the gaps yourself. Didn't really need them. A film so immersive, I was amazed audience members went to the loo. Despite the water on screen and dying for a pee, I stayed till the very end. Had to. This is my life. Love movies like this. Absolutely love them.

A portrayal of a hopeless situation which turns out to be such a visceral experience that starts
from the first frame till the end credits. It's a war movie unlike any other war movie by many
terms. Sure there is despair , anger , pain , fear and most importantly terror filled in the entire
movie. But the movie never ever lets you sit and catch your breath and relax till the next heart
pounding scene comes as the entire movie is a non stop thrill ride, nor it fills you up with hope
of a victory but it states that sometimes avoiding annihilation is a triumph. This is movie is
somehow not about war it's about the terror of war, the horrific outcome and the
unforgiving-unjust nature of the war.

Christopher Nolan in his 10th film achieves a sense of fear among viewers that lasts even after
the movie has ended. There are no consoling conversations between soldiers nor any personal
choices or family details , but what there is , is the only instinct that anyone on earth is born
with, Survival. Movie doesn't waste time in developing characters and motivational dialogues
as no one in that situation will actually do that. Sure the lack of deep characters can be a sore
thumb for many but that's the point of the movie , it's about the situation and the event not
about characters. You still root for these guys and feel sad when they die in horror, without
knowing their names, and that's the beauty of the cinema that Nolan has created.
Then there is the genius of the storytelling via distinctive vantage points. All in different
timelines and without spoiling it i would tell you to read the minimal text very carefully when
these are introduced for the first time very early in the film. That just adds layers to the
storytelling which will definitely be appreciated more on a second viewing. I rather not tell you
about the cast than just that it's filled with award winners and future award winners. Without
having much to do verbally they have conveyed many things through their actions and large
portion of the credit goes to the direction.

Christopher Nolan has brought freshness to an era and genre of filmmaking that has been a
choice of directors since almost last 80 years. A war movie without many war scenes, one
which during the entire length of the movie has not shown the opposition once , as in you
definitely see enemy bullets flying , bombs jumping , aircrafts piercing air but not a single
German face up until the last minute of the movie, still you are in dead fear of the situation and
terrorized by the opposition like the Britishers and french are as if you were there. This is
mostly achieved by the beautiful practical visuals effects from Hoyte Van Hoytema and an
superbly original and chilling score by Hans Zimmer. When you go in a war movie you feel
what can a world war II movie bring to the table that's fresh, still while exiting you are left
with an experience none like any other in this category.

It's a must watch for any war movie fans or any movie fans , don't expect a one to one
gun-fight here rather than its a survival movie in which the hell is cut loose and you have
nowhere to go other than to be with them , feel with them, fear with them....
9.7 /10 AMAZing

OK - yes, Dunkirk was a good movie, yes it was a good story - but please note I used the word good twice and not some excessive superlative.  The movie quite simply misses the scale of the actual Dunkirk - and it misses by a mile.  They just didn't make an effort to show the massive undertaking that the real rescue operation at Dunkirk was....and they missed it in EVERY facet.......not enough soldiers (not even close), no where near enough boats....not enough conflict, not enough planes........it was so disappointing.  The only recent war film it can be compared to is Saving Private Ryan...which made a massive ( and quite acceptable) effort to TRY and show the intensity and insanity of D-Day beach landings......if Private Ryan gets an A for the effort (it's probably impossible to recreate D-Day on film), Dunkirk squeaks by with a low C.  An evacuation of 400,000 men that had maybe, MAYBE 5,000 actors standing in 15 lines on an open beach?  Missed it big time.  The boats?  never more that 3 or 4 Navy ships in a scene.....and, at most - maybe 25 small boats - with, sadly, a back ground of wide open, expansive ocean....no sense of intensity, no sense of urgency, no sense of scale....it looked more like a pleasant day of sailing than a military. rescue operation.... Sorry - this was an average film at best .....a rescue of 331,000 soldiers by 220 naval warships and 700 small private boats simply cannot be depicted well by 5,000 actors and 30 boats....especially with so many pull away shots showing smooth, empty beaches and wide open calm oceans...the director and producer just missed the boat

To truly appreciate Dunkirk, one not only needs certain historic empathy but also comprehensive context. Dunkirk's epic evacuation is not evident in the movie by itself. I do not get what the hype is over this movie.  Don't get me wrong, it is a decent film, but I do not believe it is anything special.  Saving Private Ryan, Enemy at the Gates, Downfall, and Inglourious Basterds are far more engaging and tell a better war story.

One of the issues I have with the film is that it is intense from start to finish, never allowing the audience a real breather, to the point where it becomes fatiguing.  As a result, I often found my thoughts wandering rather than staying focused on the film.

A good film should always hold the attention and interest of its audience, and keep the audience's focus on the film from start to finish -  this film fails to do that.

Another issue I have is towards the very end of the film.  Without giving anything away, the sequence of events with the plane comes across as implausible.  Up until this sequence of events, Christopher Nolan and co. had done a good job with the bridging shots/composition/whatever-the-proper-term-is...but with this scene it just seems to fall apart and hurts the immersion.

DUNKIRK is a different kind of war movie. Unlike other films in the genre, this film has few obviously named characters, no overt bullet holes or blood splatter, and no obvious narrative arc. Instead, it depicts three arenas: land (primarily beachfront), sea, and air. And where other directors use multiple quick cuts and slow-mo and repeated views of the same scene from different angles to capture explosions and deaths in the greatest possible coverage, Christopher Nolan doesn't do any of that, preferring to let the story unveil in long, unbroken cuts unmarred by quick shots, slow-mo, or the usual war movie camera tricks. Instead, he uses another mechanism which I won't spoil and it accomplishes the same thing in a radically different way. It is a way of telling the story that leans on the viewer to understand, the follow along, and when I fully understood what he was doing, I was blown away. 

In this film, things like torpedoes and dropped bombs don't sound overblown but rather have the sense of authenticity. If anything, the lack of Hollywood mega-explosions make the sound of munitions in this film all the more creepy. A scene in the belly of a small tramp freighter where Germans were shooting randomly into the hull was particularly freaky, not because of some constant barrage but because of the random nature of the shots.

DUNKIRK begins almost immediately with the British and French forces in peril, pinned by blitzkrieging German forces back against the beach. Leaflets fall in the first scene showing how surrounded they are and the beach where they are is not optimal for loading men on destroyers. Nolan shows a number of ships sinking in this film and it looks for all the world to me like they were real ships really scuttled.

Nolan is famous for preferring in-camera practical effects and shooting with real film, and that is a real strength here. The film was reportedly made using 70mm film captured with IMAX cameras, the first feature film I know of that is filmed 100% with IMAX cameras. When seen on the right screen with the right sound system, the sensory effect is stunning, nearly overwhelming. An early scene with diving Stuka bombers filled me with dread, a sonic assault which I was later informed was a deliberate propaganda design decision.

There is never any indication that the Brits will be able to 'win' this battle. Indeed, the best they can hope for is anything less than the complete annihilation or capture of 400,000 troops, a setback that would essentially knock Britain out of the war. And yet the leaders on the dock overseeing the recovery efforts never lose faith, never lose their cool, keeping hoping that something will salvage the day. There is a real 'miracle of Dunkirk' which was not depicted here but it's a fascinating bit of history.

I very much enjoyed all aspects of this film but my absolute favorite sequences were the aerial scenes. Tom Hardy stands out for how much emotion he conveyed using just his eyes. (He's a master of 'less is more.' My son remembered how Hardy owned LAWLESS with few lines and an expressive series of grunts.) Furthermore, a pilot friend of mine marveled at the attention to detail in the RAF pilot gear. He said the angled goggles were period-correct and the reason why it's better for a pilot to bail out in the air versus ditching in the water is frequently the frame would bend on impact and the cockpit canopy would become difficult or impossible to open from within. The scenes in the air depicted how valiant and desperate the RAF pilots were, and how indispensable the air cover was.

Perhaps my favorite aspect of the film were the various moral dilemmas faced by all the desperate men and how they handled themselves. There's a subplot with a soldier who doesn't speak and it played out like a Greek tragedy.

Overall, this was a genre film told in a fresh way where the result of the story was stunning and magnificent. Nolan told the story in a clear but clever way which minimized the uber-violence but maximized the human peril of a dire situation. And finally,  featuring what looked like a cast of thousands and filmed with practical effects and super sharp IMAX cameras, the overall effect was the greatest sensory experience I've ever had in the theater.
