There is something truly mesmerizing about Christopher Nolan's epic film, "Dunkirk." As the director has stated in recent interviews, "Dunkirk" is not a war film; it is a film about survival. It turns out that "Dunkirk," a film that follows British forces during the events of World War II, is just that. In fact, this film goes against the status quo of most war movie epics of the past twenty or so years. "Dunkirk" is a PG-13, gore-less masterpiece. Unlike "Saving Private Ryan," "Hacksaw Ridge," "Platoon," and "Apocalypse Now" (among others) that rely heavily of blood and vulgarity, "Dunkirk" relies on the story itself to deliver relentless tension and shock to a film that is under two hours long.

The film follows three story lines: air, land and sea. It is important to note that each story, while connected with each other, serve different timelines. In fact, the land story arc, which follows Tommy (newcomer Fionn Whitehead) and the 400,000 stranded soldiers on the beaches of Dunkirk, shows time over the course of one week. The sea story arc, which follows Mr. Dawson (Academy Award winner Mark Rylance) and the civilian response to help rescue the stranded soldiers, is over the course of a day. Finally the air story arc, that follows Farrier (Tom Hardy) and his efforts to counter enemy combatants in the air, is over the course of one hour. Throughout the film, the story arcs shift to show different viewpoints of the evacuation of Dunkirk. While it may seem confusing with the overlapping story lines, the film never looses the viewer. Christopher Nolan masterfully directs the flow of the film to the point that each story ends with one another.

Throughout the film's 107 minute runtime, "Dunkirk" never lets go of the tension. The film begins with Tommy and his comrades being ambushed by unknown forces in a town outside the beaches of Dunkirk. From there, the film never lets up until the credits begin to roll less than two hours later. Part of this comes from the fantastic sound editing that mimics the sound of war perfectly. Bullets penetrating objects end with a sharp, piercing sound that gets the viewers attention. Explosions are sudden and catch you by surprise. In addition to the sound, the lack of CGI adds to the realism of the action set pieces. Christopher Nolan, instead of using an overabundance of CGI, used real military planes and warships to reenact the Battle of Dunkirk. In fact, there is so little CGI that Nolan decided to use cardboard fill ins for soldiers on the beach. It is the little details like those that add to the masterpiece that is "Dunkirk."

While it has a lot of positives, "Dunkirk" does have its flaws. Due to a lack in dialogue and a short run time, "Dunkirk" almost feels like it is half filled. Besides Mr. Dawson, the characters introduced are never developed further than their names. This negatively affects the film as a whole when watching the action scenes. With little character development, I felt distant from the characters and did not have the want to root for them as much. While Christopher Nolan wanted to focus on the person's willingness to survive instead of his backstory, it does feel like something is missing. That being said, the horrors of World War II have been told in over a dozen films and Christopher Nolan acknowledges that. He wanted to focus on the fear of the soldiers and the courage of civilians without having this character's speak it. And it is done marvelously.

"Dunkirk" is an exceptional film about survival and courage. With less focus on CGI and more efforts going into story arcs that leaves us catching our breathes, "Dunkirk" is one of the best "war" films ever made. If anyone thinks that a bloodless war film would not be great, try this one.

While the film is visually very good, it seems to portray an attitude of 'every man for himself' whereas in fact the evacuation was an excellent piece of disciplined withdrawal under exceptional circumstances.  The lack of aggression by the withdrawing troops toward attacking aircraft is limited to one man using his enfield 303 whereas in fact the troops were encouraged to use every weapon at their disposal to shoot at attacking aircraft even if only to keep up moral.  I also note some very poor continuity through the film and factual mistakes.  The Spitfire landing on a sandy beach was unlikely to have used his undercarriage since that would have caused more damaged than a 'belly flop' tail first.  Added to that was the large 'container terminal visible in the background which of course did not exist until the 1960's. Like wise the 'fully illuminated' railway station during the blackout was almost as bad as the very 'modern' railway carriages used.  There were several other factors which would perhaps not be so noticeable by a younger generation but certainly such things would reduce the authenticity of the film to older viewers.  Finally I have to say the totally ignored the actions those very brave defenders who gave lives and many years of freedom (particularly French) to hold back the German attacks for such a long time to enable their comrades escape.
another one of Nolan's masterpieces, Dunkirk without a doubt is one of the best war films of all time!

An intimate, daringly claustrophobic spectacle that transfixes the audience from opening sequence beyond. Dunkirk, spares the blaring action sequences, the large pugnacious combat, and even the expected melodrama. This is a strikingly, terrifying two-hour display of human emotion coursed throughout three perspectives; one on land, one on sea, and an hour in the sky. All equally enthralling, and dovetail in the coming conclusion of the film, very nicely. Nolan's greatest strengths and shortcomings are ostensible in this heart-thumping, survivalist narrative- but fortunately the shortcomings are few and far between.  Dunkirk follows a collective group of Allied soldiers during the year of 1940, pushed practically into the sea by German fleets along the French shorline. There seems to be little to no silver lining amongst the dreary, ominous threat that looms over them, but they must put their heads down and sink or swim. Dunkirk revels in this flustered mindset- fully embracing it and driving the narrative fullspeed until the lights go up.But what will quickly become apparent, and drastically salient for fanatics of the genre, is that Dunkirk draws away from fleshing out the individual souls at sea, land or roaring through the sky (save a few), rather it dramatizes the heavy circumstances that weigh on the thousands of soldiers collectively. This struck me as peculiar at first, as it did subvert my expectations. Which in retrospect, I shouldn't have been with the Nolan headlining every poster in heavy ink, but it draws subtle sentiments to classic expectations- without leaving a tiresome strain on the audience. Hitchcock's own survivalist war film: Lifeboat, garnered my attention in its own way, but was much more concentrated on melodramatic dialogue- but its characters strayed just slightly off stereotypical that it subverted expectation in its own way. With this film in mind, it only leads me to the conclusion of how far Nolan has taken this genre.

Nolan's ambitious narrative style really pays off, as the strings that are strung early on, tie a satisfying bow as the final act comes around. As a viewer, the tale draws both expansively to the large groups of soldiers on the brink of death with every turn, and synonymously orchestrates a picture of terrifying claustrophobia. The gritty, heart-rending, robust visuals lifting the stakes with every detail, and accentuated adequately with Hans Zimmer's score which is rhythmically similar to a ticking bomb. All this collectively, completes a message of ominous doom that seems inescapable.

The large cast of extras, and stars conflate nicely with the work behind the camera; drawing even more attention to the scale. Although, sometimes running together, a few exist salient throughout, including; Tom Hardy, who plays a pilot fending off German planes, as soldiers like Harry Styles (among a trio of soldiers) who scurry from the town along France's shoreline, towards a prayer for a serendipitous route of escape, to Mark Rylance, who plays an intrepid older gentleman who journeys into the war zone along with teenage sons, in search of soldiers to rescue. And Tom Hardy, isn't the only villain from Nolan's Batman trilogy who is casted in Dunkirk; Cillian Murphy gives a gripping performance, although much like others is dealt with few lines from an overall stingy script in that regard. Ofensiva y desatinada, esto podría resumir esta farsa de película nacionalista. Gracias a Nolan, una gran parte del mundo nunca entenderá lo que pasó en esa playa a finales del mayo de 1940 donde murieron unas 30 mil personas y donde los alemanes capturaron unos 100 mil prisioneros y donde los aliados perdieron miles de toneladas de equipo y unos 50 mil vehículos. No se hace justicia al ejército francés ni al belga ni mucho menos a los batallones indios que estuvieron presentes. El hecho de montar las tres historias de la operación "Dynamo" en una sola línea de tiempo es muy buen recurso, la línea de los aviones Spitfire, la línea de los barcos civiles y la línea de los soldados escapando pero para muchos resultará confuso ya que son líneas de tiempo diferentes que se sobrelapan solo al final. Cinematográficamente es preciosa pero resulta aburrida y sin sustento. Lástima por Nolan que venía tan bien, hubiera hecho su película de guerra de ficción y se hubiera evitado tantos problemas tontos.

Dunkirk is another visual masterpiece from Christopher Nolan. Rather than focus on a single story of protagonist the film instead loosely follows three stories that fit into the wider experience of Dunkirk. You will not come away from the film with a greater historical knowledge of the event, however you will come away feeling as if you have experienced just a snippet of what those who were involved in the war went through. The soundtrack from Hans Zimmer creates a true sense of suspense and enables the audience to be sucked into the world that Nolan is attempting to recreate. The overall story arch is nothing revolutionary or new but the visual experience of the film is simply breathtaking. 4/5.

Dunkirk delivers a well-rounded theatre experience that will be nearly impossible to translate to the small screen. 

Perhaps my expectations were too high, but Dunkirk really didn't come close to meeting them. Nolan's first (and likely only) hand at a WWII epic is carried by masterful cinematography almost to a fault. 

An evasive chronology almost necessitates the Zimmer score which often times seemed like a lawyer leading a witness. In this film, the Germans are entirely faceless, lingering in the skies above and the streets behind, and there is nary a mention of the enemy in the film, which I found odd. 

I expected to come out of the theatre with an easy 4 to 5 star review, but this film lacked most of what makes an epic WWII film...epic. There were over 300,000 casualties in the nine day evacuation, but thus film focuses on the survival of a select few, without ever humanizing them. 

I want to say that this film needs an R rating to deliver what I was expecting, but I suspect that given the narrative and theme Nolan was pursuing, PG-13 was on the money. 

If you're expecting a depiction of the utter desperation and suffering of the soldiers at Dunkirk, you will be as disappointed as I was. If you can see the film for what it is, you'll likely come away loving it.

The Miracle of Dunkirk:

Staying awake for the whole thing!

Ok so I am a history buff and know my share about WW2. If I didn't, I would have been completely lost following this plot. I wanted to see this thinking it might be a sort of British Private Ryan or something. Not!

For entirely too much time we follow the rather blah storyline of a couple of soldiers scared apparently speechless, trying to escape the unfelt and except for the occasional Stuka, unseen German onslaught. 

So, there are some great things about this film that I really enjoyed: 

The scenes with Spitfires were super cool and had the most excitement and suspense in the whole movie except for possibly some of the boat scenes.

The cinematography was beautiful and captured the scene and feel very well. I saw it in XD. Just gorgeous.

Mark Rylance gave a great performance as the stoic, understated Englishman determined to make a difference. Kenneth Branagh did well in his limited screen time as the captain in charge of the evacuation. 

Too little time was spent on the evacuation. All of a sudden it just happens. Apparently, there was no drama or struggle to organize and carrying out the evacuation of 300,000+ soldiers other than having Branagh stand on the end of a pier looking longingly for the little boats to show up.  Perhaps? 

It is a pity that such a historically significant event was given such an uninteresting treatment. So much more could have been done with this, but it looked too much like a khaki-clad army of zombies cueing on a beach waiting for a shipment of brains to snack on. 

If there could have been context, like showing these guys had the poop kicked out of them (i.e. battle scenes)and that's why they're just standing around, or having desperate leaders up day and night organizing SOMETHING(drama) it would give the story more bite. A shame really. Even Churchill's epic speech was read second hand by the mostly mum soldier in a near whisper. 
 Oh well.

This movie was just plain awful. This is by far the loudest silent film I've ever seen. Pretty much all of the dialogue in this movie can be found in the trailer. The main characters are poorly established and I couldn't make any connection with any of them. The point of any film is to get the audience to care about the characters in it and this film fails at this spectacularly. The whole movie was just action shots and explosions. I felt like an alien that just happened to be floating by in a spaceship observing world war II, which is to say it's all action with absolutely no context or understanding. Do not waste your time and money with this movie.

This movie was a chance to show some history but I found the history was diminished by some shallow, unbelievable and poorly written side stories.  The spitfire episode, if actually historically accurate, was very inaccurate in terms of aviation principles and physics.  A fighter pilot would never watch and ignore a bomber lining up on a friendly ship to bomb it while deciding to continue back to base because he was low on fuel.  The ships at sea were anchored during battle and/or taking their time exiting the danger area.  If this is really how the British fought war and evacuated their troops, which I doubt, then it is a miracle they survived for a few more months. I think this movie could have been directed much better, but it appears they were on a time schedule that was more important than accuracy in marine and air operations during WWII.
Not historically authentic, does not communicate the scale of the effort, very limited human drama, logically weak.

Container cranes in the background that didn't exist till the 60's.   hated it.  Waste of money.   Didn't learn a thing about the history of it.

There isn't much dialog, so mumbling and accents, don't help. 

Also unhelpful was the fact that so many of the actors looked alike.

Dunkirk is riveting and intense. This movie was flat out boring.  I don't even know why they bothered to put Cillian Murphy and Tom Hardy in this because anybody could have played the two characters.  Cillian Murphy does absolutely nothing and Tom Hardy flies a magic plane with a broken fuel gauge because Hollywood had to figure out some way to make his plane fly forever while all his wingmates flamed out long before.  Tom Hardy flies the ONLY plane to make it all the way to Dunkirk and he heroically saves everyone on the beach single handedly in plane that has absolutely no fuel left in it.  Kenneth Branaugh paces up and down the pier in immaculate naval uniform dispensing folksy wisdom and showing grave concern while everyone else is getting the **** bombed out of them and strafed.  Mark Rylance doesn't do squat either except show you how a timid pleasure boat yachter can still get up the nerve to steer his boat over to Dunkirk to pick up a few of the lads.  Yet another in a long string of "audience favs" that I just didn't agree with.

Apparently made by someone who thinks the tired old Hollywood war movie clichés are what makes a story good.  The group of soldiers who see the Stuka coming, and close their eyes because they know they are about to die, only to have a british plane come out of nowhere and save the day...the pilot who sees a bomber about to drop his bomb on a ship full of wounded, and then shoots down the bomber at the last second to save the day...or the boat captain who sees an ME-109 about to strafe the boat, so he tricks the German pilot into thinking he won't turn the boat, but then turns at the last second to foil the attack, after which the ME-109 just gives up...or the group of soldiers who think they're trapped, but then one of them figures out that, based on the shot grouping, the Germans are really only just doing target practice (in the middle of the battle mind you)...it was all just very silly and stupid, and is not how people really act in battle.  Oh yeah...the Spitfire that runs out of gas and has his engine quit, and is about to ditch, but then sees a German Stuka about to drop a bomb, so he goes and shoots him down real quick, and then finishes ditching.  Not sure how you do that after your engine has quit, but ok.  And of course, the last soldier to be evacuated has to be woken up on the pier, by the admiral calling him from the end of the pier...I guess they just had to have the last guy run to the boat, and that's the only thing they could think of.
The whole movie is like that.  They wanted to make a bunch of tires old clichés from past movies and have us believe that it's history.

Ever since Memento I have looked forward to Christopher Nolan films, and I have been looking forward to his latest movie, Dunkirk, ever since I heard about it.  Having seen the film tonight I have very mixed feelings about it.  On the positive side, the acting was very good and the action sequences came across as very authentic.  Once again,  Nolan uses time shifting to portray three different strands of the film seemingly happening at the same time but which cover differing period of time (the beach sequences cover a week, the boat sequneces a day and the air sequences just one hour).  This is confusing as it appears at the start of the film that each strand begins at the same time yet but they also seem to converge together at the end of the film (when they clearly cant if covering different time periods!).  My two biggest gripes about the film, which ultimately dragged the film down for me from what could have been epic to mixed, were the characters themselves (I really couldnt invest any emotional attachment to them) and particularly the lack of scale of the task at hand. 
 In reality this was an epic story but the scale of the film just didn't convey this for me with just a fraction of the actual men, boats, planes etc that were involved the the evacuation.  I appreciate Nolan decided not to use CGI to go for realism but for me this lack of scale ultimately disappointed.

A departure from his typical science fiction fare, Christopher Nolan has come to prove that he can do war just as well, and he has. Dunkirk is an audiovisual spectacle, incorporating Nolan's penchant for nonlinear narrative with gripping cinematography and another pitch-perfect soundtrack.

The ensemble cast delivers across the board, including Harry Styles of all people, and the minimal dialogue is more than enough to convey the fears and the emotions that is all to clear in the faces of the soldiers on that beach. The dialogue is nigh impossible to decipher at times - it's not just the accent - and the runtime leaves room for deeper exploration, but Dunkirk is a very memorable film that should endure the test of time.

The movie does not get across the scale of the effort, has a weird time shift with editing from day to night to day (I completly lost track at this point in time) and follows the story of a ship which left me underwhelmed at the end.

In an age where CGI allows us to have 10000 orcs and armies on screen, this movie shows 8 luftwaffer, 9 RAF and 12 merchant boats all on 1 day.

The actual dunkirk events was 8 days, 16 RAF squadrons and 800 boats - the scale this move fails to make felt or deliver - yes the emotion is there, but not the scale and that left the movie flat.

First off, I am not a "wordy" reviewer. My goal here is to not "WOW" an audience with an extensive vocabulary, but rather just share my feelings/opinions about the movie. Dunkirk was an interesting film, in regards to the second World War, but boring . Expectations can be a bad thing when it comes to movies especially when we are inclined to compare other movies of a similar genre. With that being said Dunkirk started out with similar elements of a war movie with intense background music and vague screenplay that would draw someone to the edge of there seats, but then failed to deliver the "war" part of the movie. 

After the movie there was a father and son walking in front of me out of the theater and I heard the dad say to his son" That movie had me tense through the whole movie." I thought, why? Nothing happened! Again, perhaps my expectations weren't necessarily too high or low, but rather just misplaced on what the purpose of the movie was to be.
If you are expecting blood and war scene, Dunkirk is not for you. It is more of a documentary feel and weirdly enough, it fits better under the category of suspense rather than action.

Nolan really drops the ball w/ this disappointed and disjointed mini-epic concerning a crucial and vitally important chapter in British history.

I understand it would be almost impossible to provide 300,000 British and French and Allied troops, an armada of warplanes from both sides, and hundreds of ships of all sizes, to recreate w/ any decent scope the enormity of the "Miracle of Dunkirk" as it was. But perhaps that's why it shouldn't have been done, and certainly not by a director known for his flair, and for telling fanciful stories as opposed to hard-hitting, cohesive ones.

The cinematography is nice, the acting is alright, the limited dogfights were a hoot to watch...that's the best I can say about this disjointed, random-feeling film. It has as much emotion as tuna salad, except for those moments which were drummed-up in contrived fashions. 

For example, Admiral Branagh's hanging his head on the docks, awaited to be killed by an approaching German plane...but lo! He's saved by Tom Hardy, gliding his plane for seeming hours on no fuel, and saving all those soldiers below. 

There's a downed pilot about to drown, his canopy stuck (when aren't they stuck in films like this?) but lo! He's saved by Mark Rylance, who loses yet another son in this film, while shrugging it off...C'est la guerre, indeed.

Oh, brother. Imagine Pearl Harbor being attacked by five Zeros, sinking two ships, and killing 20 soldiers while dropping bombs that simply blast sand in the air. Or imagine Dunkirk as done on The Hallmark channel (after 10 PM) and you've seen Dunkirk as presented by Nolan. Here is a film meant to dazzle, not educate. And don't forget to bring ear-plugs if you see it in theaters, which Nolan obviously meant for you to do; seriously, how about a film that looks good AT HOME as well as in cinemas, which fewer and fewer people are even attending anymore?

Normally a treat, Christopher Nolan's signature style plays out as a gimmick in Dunkirk. Too much of the nonlinear storyline plays off of assumptions about the audience - assumptions like the audience already knows the historical significance of Dunkirk, or that we can tell one oil-covered white-faced Brit from another, or which fighter jet cockpit we're in from one choppy scene to the next, or what is meant when subtitles cryptically announce "one week" and "one day" and "one hour," or even what time in history we're watching: I literally didn't know which world war this movie was about until a passing reference to Churchill, and trust me when I say it is not my responsibility to do research before sitting in the theater. Nolan missed the mark in this overly ambitious, poorly executed, and annoyingly presumptuous war film.
Music tried to make drama where there was none.

Writer-director Christopher Nolan has perfected his craft so well by now, that it is no so surprise "Dunkirk" has become one of 2017's biggest and successful films. Based on the true story, "Dunkirk" showcases spectacular cinematography in grand fashion as well as an ensemble cast that delivers gripping performances. This film was made for IMAX as Nolan puts the audience in some thrilling aerial stunts and some fast-paced ground action. What is the most thrilling part of the film is that you never actually see the enemy, that it is assumed they are watching the characters from the distance, and that is a fear that will resonate too close to home for some Veterans.

Total immersion in the film as if you were in one of the troops. Great to have a movie with so little dialogue and appreciate that the director and screenwriters knew the film's imagery and the faces of the men conveyed as much as the words. Beautiful.

The story of the historical Dunkirk is the immensity of the problem of evacuating more than 300,000 British soldiers, representing the best of the UK's military that the nation knew would be vital in protecting the island from German invasion following the disaster of Allied collapse in Europe. So I expected the film to focus on this theme, but what we got was a series of vignettes surrounding an RAF pilot, a young British and French soldier trying desperately to get off the beach, and the crew of a small British civilian watercraft and their efforts to assist in the evacuation. What was missing was the sweeping immensity of the pending tragedy. We were treated to beach scenes with pristine groomed sands and almost no soldiers. The flotilla of boats that in reality was over 800 was never more than a few dozen in the movie. The whole immensity of the story was lost by ignoring these basic physical facts. Add to that, disjointed editing and it slow pacing and it all added up to one big disappointment for me.

Amazing movie, amazing story telling, well written, directed and produced. A case of where less is more. The monotony of war, the viciousness of the Nazis, the sheer horror of being trapped, all captured with a subtle touch one does not normally expect from a war movie..
Great but lack of substance and emotion.

The flow is amazingly disjointed jumping from plot scene to plot scene with the addition of disjointed flashbacks regarding at least one character. One minute we are in daylight; the next minute we are at nighttime; then back to daylight and so on . . . Yet this is all supposed to be taking place within 24 hours I gather. It does have an amazing series where a Spitfire which has run out of fuel manages to continue flying for about 10 minutes and even with a stationary prop is able to take out a German aircraft. Wow, I'm sure that is pretty well just like it was.
Wonderfully shot...it's the most beautiful movie I've seen this year. It isn't a flawless epic but it is worth a watch

The soundtrack could be used as a form of torture and the only cool part of the movie was the airplane skirmishes and the emotional moments.  This movie was a lot of hype and very little substance.

Dunkirk, more like Dung-Crap! I have no idea why this movie received good reviews. Let me start with the good. This movie looked and sounded great in I-Max, and I saw this movie on $5 Tuesday. That's the end of the good. Now to the bad. This movie had no characters. I felt zero emotional connection to anyone in this movie. I didn't care if anyone lived or died or anything. Mark Rylance's (the BFG) character was the only one who was halfway interesting. He was the only character who had a decent amount of dialogue in the film, who had a clear goal, and who made decisions. The other character that had more than 5 lines in the picture was Kenneth Branagh's. He seemed utterly pointless. It seemed like he was watching the movie, and his purpose was just to say a cheesy lines about "Home" every once in a while. Tom Hardy's character was boring and repetitive, only to predictably save the day in the end. Because this movie is so messed up, it is really hard to decide who the main character is, but if I had to decide, it'd be the guy we see 1st. He is very forgettable. He looks and acts almost identical to his friend and almost everyone in the whole movie. He meets his friend while he is taking a dump. This is not a joke. So the main character doesn't poop. He stops and helps his new friend bury a body. And the guy doesn't poop the whole movie. And him and his new friend just try to escape the whole movie. That leads me to my second point: there is no plot. It's just a bunch of explosions. There's more plot in a Transformers movie. 'Poop guy' and 'bury dead body guy' just go from ship to ship trying to live. By the way, the movie is almost over before 'bury dead body guy' says anything. So these guys try to live, Kenneth Branagh stands on a dock and says things that don't matter, Mark Rylance picks up survivors in his boat, and Tom Hardy shoots other planes, while in his plane, over and over and over again, while not being seen or heard. And that's your movie. I kept waiting for the opening action sequence to be over. I kept waiting for it to slow down a little and have some exposition, but it never did. It was like I missed the beginning and just tuned into the climax of a long, humorless, silent picture. That's not to say that a movie can't be action packed and be great. U-571 is an example of a nearly non-stop, action packed, WWII movie, thrill ride. U-571 managed to have memorable and distinct characters with different purposes. U-571 had a plot with a clear goal and twists and turns. If Dunkirk could've just cut out some of the unnecessary bits, like Kenneth Branagh, and had the 1st half hour be set up and character development, then it could've been really good. But as it was, I didn't care about any of it. I kept watching English soldiers die and thinking, "I don't care. This movie didn't make me care." As simple as the plot for Dunkirk was, the movie was really confusing. You'd think if you're going for an exciting, action thriller, that a simple linear plot would suffice. This movie jumps all over the timeline without giving any hint that it just made a jump in time. Christopher Nolan does a great job of jumping all over the timeline in his movie Memento. In Memento, he manages to keep things coherent and engaging. Not so here. This is just disappointing. The time jumping is completely unnecessary here. What little dialogue there is in this film is really hard to hear because of thick accents, loud explosions, masks over faces, and the music being really loud in the mix. With a really simple plot that is really hard to follow and characters with zero development or even distinguishing traits, I found myself in a really big struggle to care about what I was watching, even with incredible imagery and sound design. Yet, the whole time, the movie was telling me what I was watching was really exciting with it's music score. And that leads me to my last point: I hated the music. It pains me to say that because I usually love Hans Zimmer, especially under the direction of Christopher Nolan. There is virtually no melody in this score. It's relentless and annoying. I guess I can't blame Zimmer, considering he was just scoring to picture. Imagine watching The Dark Knight, but during the entire movie all you heard was The Joker's theme, non-stop. That's what it's like. The whole soundtrack may as well just be an air raid siren. And it's not just the music. The sound effects, as incredible as they were, were also loud, annoying, and relentless. At times, I found myself covering my ears. I thought, "Why am I paying money to cover my ears? What I'm covering my ears to is what I paid for." You know what movie is better than this: all the movies I have seen this year. Valerian and The Mummy were even better. They were at least fun. The best movie I've seen this Summer is War for the Planet of the Apes, but you really need to see all the Apes pictures to get the full enjoyment out of that one. The next best is Spider-Man: Homecoming, but maybe you're not up to date with the Marvel movies. In that case, see Wonder Woman. You don't need to see the other DC movies to enjoy that one. But what ever you do, don't see Dunkirk. I beg of you not to give that garbage your support.

What an experience. Highlights the horrors of war, contrasted with young men simply trying to do their jobs as soldiers, and civilians attempting to help the war effort wherever they could, even by putting their lives at stake.
We saw this in the IMAX theatre on 70mm film, and it was an incredible visual spectacle. The screen and picture was massive and detailed, and the sound was pulsing and piercing so much to the extent that nearly every gunshot was frighteningly loud, to great effect. 
The performances of the actors was good, with their fears and insecurities on display, but often difficult to tell the soldiers apart from each other (maybe that was the director's intention, to show that they were all just interchangeable young men when thrown into battle).
The music and sound was intense and scary, with ticking clocks or watches interspersing the musical score, to give a sense of urgency. 
Clocking in under 2 hours, it was a great use of time, as many films lately are over the 2 hour point, which is when I tend to get bored. This film had my attention constantly, with a few exceptions while we were viewing the cockpit of a fighter plane, but those sequences illustrated the patience required by the pilots to get those perfect shots to take down an enemy. 
Such a great film, nice to see there are still good Second World War films to be made. Definitely see this in the theatre if you can!
Watched at Chinook in 70mm IMAX, with Sam, Andy, Clay, and Billy, July 23, 2017.

I just got home from watching "Dunkirk" and oh my goodness. There aren't words in the English language to describe how awesome and impacting Dunkirk was. Instead of focusing on the typical niches and cliches of most war films, Dunkirk focuses on the brutal reality of war that is commonly overlooked, survival. Dunkirk takes you back to when Nazi Germany had the upper hand, claimed France, and their plan for Global conquest looked all to real. Christopher Nolan shows how wars are truly won, the unconditional love that civilians have for their military and far they are willing to go to rescue their champions. Saving Private Ryan, Flags of our Fathers, Letters From Iwo Jima, Patton, and Pearl Harbor have company.

Only reason for one star is the cinematography was excellent, and the acting was good.
Absolutely brilliant. And beautiful to watch.

Christopher Nolan's "Dunkirk" reaffirms just how powerful the movies can be when it comes to placing viewers in the moment. In this case, the moment is 1940 during World War II. The place is the French city of Dunkirk, where British soldiers have retreated to the coast after the German army has literally pushed them to the edge of the country. Under the most harrowing of conditions, these young men will endure, await rescue, and grow restless with uncertainty.

"Dunkirk" is not only a superb film cinematically, with production (and post-production) values of the highest caliber, but the fact that it depicts and recreates a significant yet mostly unknown historical event makes it all the more meaningful. It opens our eyes, minds and hearts to what some soldiers during World War II had to bear. This isn't pleasant or romantic viewing, but it's nonetheless essential and incredibly riveting.

As a "war picture," "Dunkirk" isn't as concerned about context as much as sensation, and yet this doesn't make it any less intellectually stimulating. The action that unfolds keeps our minds racing. Nolan, who also wrote the screenplay, introduces us to the battle at hand with just a few lines of white text over a black screen, and then, fade in: a gun fires-loudly. From here on out, the film never stops moving, cutting back and forth between three different but equally nerve-wracking narratives. If anything, the film makes us incredibly grateful we're not any of the characters, who are mostly nameless soldiers and commanders who remain determined yet are losing hope and feeling abandoned by their country, the leaders of which refuse to surrender to Germany but still commit to evacuating its 30,000 plus men from the area, although this will be no small feat. 

When we first meet the soldiers, their situations are already dire, and over the next few days, things will only get worse. On the beach, massive lines for would-be evacuation boats have formed and there's clearly not enough room for everybody. Meanwhile, bullets fly from all directions, bombs get dropped by the Luftwaffe above, and some men resort to suicide by walking out into the ocean and never coming back. 

Those who have chosen survival will brave conditions that are cold, wet and dark. There will also be moments when the ability to breathe isn't a guarantee and one's options are to either drown or burn. But on top of the physical hardships, there are emotional and psychological traumas, some of which stem from not feeling like you belong and/or not trusting your comrades.

Many war movies recreate degrees of these situations all the time, but there's often a safe, comfortable distance between them and the viewers. "Dunkirk" is an exception. It's more raw and palpable. The soundtrack, photography and special effects, which are seamless, envelop us to the point where we feel like we're right there with these men, and not in a fun way. What they feel, we feel, and it's rough. We leave the theater with a legitimate sense of what it might have been like to be a soldier at Dunkirk.

Amidst the madness, Nolan refrains from investing too much time in any one character, which is wise because it's clear from the beginning no one is guaranteed to survive. In fact, the people in the film aren't characters as much as faces to which we can identify the current narrative. A similar strategy was practiced by Ridley Scott in "Black Hawk Down," which, like "Dunkirk," was less about the people and more about how the conditions affected the people. 

On land, we follow Tommy (Fionn Whitehead), who, after outrunning snipers, partners with another youth-faced soldier and attempts to use a wounded man on a stretcher as his ticket to get about a board an exiting boat. This effort, though, like many thereafter, quickly proves futile.

In the air, two spitfire pilots (Tom Hardy and Jack Lowden) make their way over Dunkirk to fend off the looming Luftwaffe, but the Englishmen are low on fuel, and they spend so much time dodging bullets themselves, their mission shifts from rescuing and protecting those to simply evading danger.

With limited resources, Commander Bolton (Kenneth Branagh) receives word the Royal Navy has enlisted private citizens to use their own boats to make their way across the English Channel and pick up the soldiers. Nolan shows us this perspective through Mr. Dawson (Mark Rylance) and his son Peter (Tom Glynn-Carney), along with Peter's friend, George (Barry Keoghan). As they make their way to Dunkirk, they happen upon a traumatized soldier (Cillian Murphy), who chides Dawson for willingly taking them back into the chaos, but even after a tragedy occurs, Dawson remains steadfast in fulfilling what he believes is his duty.

Even though the film constantly shifts across its multiple stories, Nolan and his longtime editor, Lee Smith, keep each narrative afloat by incorporating it with a growing sense of urgency. As the peril and exhaustion of the allies heightens, so too does the film's tension, and it's created and held so masterfully that we find our own bodies tightening up. We're with the characters as their minds race with incertitude, not knowing if they'll be able to breathe, or if they'll have enough fuel, or if their landing gear will open, or if they'll be viewed by their fellow country men and women as cowards or heroes.

By being such a convincing war film, "Dunkirk" invariably ends up as an "anti-war" film. Why? Because after seeing it, we can't imagine anyone thinking war is worth the fear, anxiety and physical misery these men faced, and even though its politics are mostly muted, we get the sense Nolan wanted to tell a story that depicted heroism but also served as a cautionary about what can happen when countries choose to violence to resolve issues. 

No matter your politics or how you interpret the film's message, "Dunkirk" is simply breathtaking. Its sounds and visuals stir us and keeps the film's tension locked right up to the end. It didn't seem possible that Christopher Nolan's standards and abilities could beyond the high level they were already at, but "Dunkirk" shows he's gained a greater knowledge of how to make viewers feel they're someplace else, and even though Dunkirk is a place we don't want to be, the film allows us to recognize those who were there and what they experienced.

If you like acting, or plot, then you will find little in Dunkirk. While the visual storytelling starts off promisingly, it quickly devolves into repetitive action sequences of explosions, dog-fights and gunfire jump-scares. The movie wastes its talented actors by turning them into a backdrop; it wastes its occasionally fantastic cinematography with jump-cuts between its tenuously connected threads; and it wastes Warner Hertzog's musical score with its non-linear pacing and failure to resolve any tension in the music for an hour-and-a-half. No matter how much action there is, or how intense that it might get, without purpose or resolution, it becomes monotonous and boring. I went in expecting Saving Private Ryan and what I got was Pearl Harbor, minus the story.
A masterpiece from Nolan.

A remarkable movie about the absurdity of war. Very intense but without shedding of blood and flesh, and endless scenes with guns firing, or people who explode for half an hour as you see typically in American war movies.  Nolan had the intelligence to keep a certain decency over that. There are no heroes or villains in this movie; the main character is the war.  Without telling the story of a single character, he managed to focus on the horror (and you really can feel the horror) that men experience during the war, but without excessive dramatization and blood. The images are amazingly beautiful.  The sound track is very efficient to keep you on the edge of your chair and in a tense state. The actors are excellent; the British actors always have something special in their way of acting. A great movie which suggests sensations, impressions, and vivid emotions. Reminds me that this kind of horror must never start again.

Ahh... Nolan. Who doesn't love Christopher Nolan, eh? One of the most acclaimed directors working today, a cinematic genius behind modern classics such as "The Dark Knight" trilogy, "The Prestige", "Inception" and "Interstellar"...
Well, I hate to be a party pooper (as always), but I have never shared the mad love every other movie fan I know has to share for him. I mean, his works are a'ight, but I never found them to be as great as everybody else seemed to think.
I guess I liked early Nolan the best - "Memento" and especially "Insomnia" -, when he was more interested in characters and building suspense than just creating the biggest baddest epics available.
Of course, Nolan is good at creating suspense and orchestrating action setpieces, but even his best works "Inception" and "Interstellar" have suffered from being overlong and pompous. Not to mention his third and last Batman which felt like a big pompous piece of crap.
Having written all that, I liked "Dunkirk" a lot. It's not only one of the finest movies of 2017 (so far), one of the most thoughtful war dramas I've seen, and also Nolan's best yet.
Although if you go to cinema expecting his usual, you may well leave disappointed, because this epic World War II tale is quite unlike anything we have come to associate him with.
After all these years, it must be supremely difficult to create a war drama with something fresh to show or say.
But Nolan is not afraid of challenges, and he has managed to pull off a movie which is both epic and intimate, artsy and mainstream-friendly, adrenaline-filled and deep at the same time. It's what the movie lovers always wait for but rarely get: a thinking man's blockbuster.
"Dunkirk" shows the experience of war from the another angle rarely seen or thought of, at least in movies. It's about human frailty, loneliness, isolation and enduring the limbo between chaos and salvation that war is made of.
Of course, there's also enough explosions and eye-candy, but the whole thing is rather artsy in a good way. Not much dialogue or clearly defined events too, just people waiting (because there's nothing else left for them to do) and trying to survive.
There is not even a single clearly-defined central character, although there are several main storylines to follow, sometimes not in chronological form.
The story is about thousands of Allied troops surrounded by enemy forces, trapped on the beach and waiting for rescuing.
We have some well-known actors here, such as Tom Hardy, Kenneth Branagh and Cillian Murphy, but it's not really an actor's movie (ie, meant to let somebody shine) but fitting everything into a carefully crafted cinematic mosaic.
Speaking about war part, I especially loved the flight and air battle scenes. The immediacy, the sound effects. Also the fact that they were often made from pilot's viewpoints, so it feels more realistic. The pilot shoots and we see target plane catching fire only after a while, for example.
All in all, Dunkirk" is the Nolan movie that has touched me the most. It's about real things, emotions and experiences, and the action is thrillng. Another beautiful achievement for one of the most liked and successful auteurs working in mainstream cinema today.
Watched it in IMAX which probably add something to the experience, at least from technical standpoint. But it's surely a good looking and sounding movie on any screen or setup, methinks.

I can understand where people may be coming from when they say there is a lack of character development in this film, and I can definitely see it. I cannot, however, justify the bland/boring statement. You need to understand what war is to like this movie for what it is, and some people seem to have a preconceived view where there is always a hero and always a villian, and the hero tears the enemy to shreds and saves the day, coming back home to his worried wife and/or child, and there's just a happy ending. This is NOT how war works. Everyone is vulnerable-anyone and everyone is mortal and can die if they are in the radius of a bomb or hit with a bullet, or are in a ship that's internally flooded- panic and struggle take over, not intellect of "Ooh, how am I gonna get out of this one?" Similarly, for character development, there isn't any for a reason- in war, do you think a commanding officer would want to get someone off the beach because he heard a story that he has a wife and family back home? If he ain't there in time, he is not getting of that boat, it would be all about getting as many people out as quickly as possible, not the people who you think are the most worthy. The film isn't character driven because it doesn't need to be- instead , it is driven by the event, the horror of war, the desperation and pushed into place by Zimmer's score. The film forces to you to not care ABOUT the characters, but BECOME them; feel and see what they feel and see: Loud and deadly gunshots, the horrific screams of the German planes engines (Which were, as a historical fact, made to crush morale,) the screams of your fellow soldiers and they die, and you can do nothing about it. I get that some people are driven by character development, but this is the most realistic and engaging view of war I personally have ever seen, and I hate to say it, but if you discount this movie based on the fact that you are too hung up on the fact that you don't know if there is a wife or family or backstory for the characters of this film, then you should reconsider your stance on how and why you view movies.

Not as great as the critics would have you believe as I fear the novelty of a "Hollywood" war movie without any Americans and a totally British subject had clouded reviewer's objectivity.
What is done well is the feeling of ordinariness of the young British squadies trying to survive against the odds and the heroic involvement of the RAF who were edited out of the historical narrative in preference to the Battle of Britain that started a couple of months later.
However the dialogue and direction of the officers is a cliched disaster and the messing of the movie timeline to give a character's POV of the key scenes is just confusing rather than innovative.
The film has spent a year in the edit suite and it shows as Christopher Nolan has been scratching his head on what to do with his masterpiece. If this film wins any awards it will be more down to the rarity of the subject than any artistic merit.

Seeing the film in 70mm IMAX was truly one of the most visceral moving-going experiences of my life. The sounds of gunshots are deafening, much louder than any other gunshot put to film. Roaring planes flying overhead the beach create a noise so intense that it shakes the IMAX screen and your seat along with it. The sound and visual design mix together to do whatever it can to fully immerse you into the experience. It's as if I was on the beach waiting to be saved; I was in the sinking ship swimming for dear life in fear of drowning; I was flying a fighter plane trying to shoot down the enemy spitfires. This is pure virtual reality without the need of hi-tech goggles.

Through beautiful camerawork and extremely immersive sound, Christopher Nolan fills us with a sense of dread that could only come with surviving a situation like "Dunkirk". Interweaving several stories keeps us engaged and instead of getting us acquainted with many of the characters, Nolan opts to make the audience feel a part of the movie. As if they are there surviving the day alongside these soldiers. You never know who may or may not survive, and even without the use of excessive blood Nolan doesn't lose the horror that war provides, and he perfectly encapsulates what a war film should be. Dunkirk is one of those movies that will be remembered forever, and it cements Nolan as an all-time great in the process (As if there was ever a doubt to begin with).

Trenchant filmmaking with converging storylines provides an almost emotionless blank canvas for telling this devastating bit of war history. The emotion is filled in with a ticking clockwork of faces, machines, geography, and the scale of war. We don't see the enemy or the blood and guts of battle, but it's no less wrenching. Fascinating telling of the greatness and sordidness of human nature.

"Dunkirk" is a war movie that takes place during World War II and describes the events of evacuating Allied soldiers from the beaches of Dunkirk in northern France. The movie is told in 3 stories, representing the land, the sea and the air...

The first story tells of a young English soldier who is the only one of his battalion to survive an attack by the Germans. He eventually reaches the British Allied troops where they are awaiting evacuation on the beaches of Dunkirk.

The second story tells of a father, his son and his son's friend who travel by small boat to Dunkirk in order to assist in the evacuation. On the way, they pick up a shell-shocked soldier who had been stranded at sea and is terrified to learn that they are going to Dunkirk where the war is taking place.

The third story tells of a pair of fighter pilots who travel to Dunkirk to give air support to the troops. One of the pilots has his plane damaged in gunfire from an enemy and must ditch into the sea, leaving the other pilot to continue to Dunkirk alone with rapidly depleting fuel.

All of the stories take place at different times and cover different lengths of time, but are interwoven throughout the movie and show different character's perspectives.

Though it has some big name actors (Mark Rylance, Kenneth Branagh, Tom Hardy), the movie doesn't rely too heavily on them. Many of the actors that play the soldiers are young and somewhat unknown. It not only allowed the movie to stand on its own without the star power, it also showed how young and inexperienced the men in the war really were.

This movie is far more action-based than dialogue-based. There is relatively little dialogue and the viewer picks up on the surrounding action and body language of the characters -- and it does it very well. The movie didn't need to be bogged down in talk. As soon as the movie starts, the viewer is thrown right into the middle of the war.

The visuals are realistically gritty and the music adds tension throughout the movie. The nonlinear storytelling and acting, both spoken and not, make this one of the most interesting war movies I've seen.

Highly recommended.

Christopher Nolan does it again. His latest, and dare I say greatest, movie is based on a true story and honors it in spectacular fashion. Dunkirk is about the true story of the Battle of Dunkirk, where thousands of British and French troops were stuck and trapped on the beaches of Dunkirk, fighting to survive while also trying to evacuate. This is a powerful story that Nolan captures beautifully. 

Visuals are phenomenal. From the beaches to the seas, this movie sucks you in and makes you feel like you are actually there. This feeling is only enhanced by tremendous sounds that are eerily realistic, something Nolan is known for. Hans Zimmer's score is fantastic and adds an increasing amount of suspense to an already suspenseful movie to begin with.

Only issue here is the lack of dialogue, which seems to have cut back on the emotion a little bit, although by the end of the movie you feel for what these men went through and why "war is hell." Dunkirk is unique in a sense that it cuts back on the dialogue to focus on the technical side of things while being able to deliver a powerful war story about the will to survive against all odds.

The characters were thinly drawn and dialogue was unimaginative ,playing to the audience in a typical Hollywood fashion.
The incredible story deserved better................

In its own weird way this is Nolan's most experimental film to date. The combination of a clock-ticking-nearly-ceaseless soundtrack, unrelenting tension, Rashomon like story structure, sparse dialogue and breathless visual splendor, "Dunkirk" manages to separate itself from the typical Nolan canon and the war genre in general. Does all this equate to it being the brilliant auteurs finest work yet? I have a strong suspicion that critics would say yes, but audiences significantly more divided. Its the anti "Saving Private Ryan", shockingly non violent, with an emphasis on the visual ballet of aerial dog fights, the suffocating closeness of the oceans peril, and the inevitable sense of empending doom. There is no character to truly attach ones emotional gravitas to, simply because we don't spend enough time with any one of them, which may be the biggest fault in the film. The lack of memorable characters gives it a sort of hollowness, with the majority of the focus falling into the structure and visuals. I'm torn. On one hand the experience of the film is brilliant, it's intense and visceral, but on the other hand, there is no face to the enemy, no individual to invest in. It feels like the an amazing amusement ride, thrilling and relentless while you're in it but when it's over you walk away with only the experience to cling to.
Really amazing movie, the best I've seen this year.

Less than satisfactory storytelling and action.  the few times a german plane began a run was the highlight of the film for me.  Shame because I feel like so much story could have been squeezed from these historic events.

It's one thing to have scenes happening in different locations, and maybe in different time periods. Cutting between the past and present isn't very confusing, as long as the audience is able to distinguish what's the past and what's the present. But when you have three timelines, happening at different time rates, it's nearly impossible to figure out what is going on. The ending of the film is a complete mess in this regard, but I won't go into details as to what actually happens. Maybe this would have worked better had we known the characters, and had grown attached to them. But Nolan tries something that, again, works on paper, but doesn't work on screen. He has a huge ensemble cast, without the film focusing on any one character in particular. We don't learn the backstories of any of these characters. I understand where he was coming from; in war, you don't know the story of the person fighting alongside you. You just have to make do with who and what you've got. But for a movie, that doesn't work. At least not for the way Nolan structures the film...

Really not quite sure why everyone is raving about this film, yes it has plenty of positives but it is unfortunately undermined by some poor decisions. Firstly the positives; it looks great, it is well shot, the score is brilliant, the majority of the main cast is solid, the sound design is spot on and it has plenty of tense moments mixed in with the decent action scenes. Sadly the film is somewhat undermined by a lackluster script that doesn't give me any reasons to care or like the characters we follow, the whole narrative which jumps between one week, one day and one hour is good in theory but removes tension from several later scenes and makes them mostly predictable, Harry Styles is completely unremarkable and the choice to go for a more audience friendly rating makes the majority of the action no where near as intense and shocking as the incredible sound design needs to back it up. Saving Private Ryan is a far better realistic depiction of WWII in Europe and that is despite that films own flaws.
Excellent film, highly recommend.
